description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: 6 Things I Learned About Ulcers
description: Halfway through February, I could no longer sleep through the night. At 2 a.m., Id find myself chugging milk from the carton to extinguish a fire at the top of my rib cage. The gnawing feeling high in my stomach alternated with nausea so arresting I kept a bucket next to my laptop and considered taking a pregnancy test, even though I was 99 percent sure I wasnt expecting.

title: The Daily: Whats Going On With the U.S. and Russia?
description: Listen and subscribe from your mobile device: On iPhone or iPad | On Android via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher

title: Which Force is More Harmful to the Arts: Elitism or Populism?
description: In Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, Adam Kirsch and Liesl Schillinger discuss the art yielded by populist and elite mind-sets.

title: At the End of Life, a Way to Go Gentle
description: While confronting the prospect of death, people like me  grappling with a diagnosis of advanced cancer  often consider what sort of care they want and how to say goodbye. Given the delicate negotiations in which the dying need to engage, do intensive care physicians with their draconian interventions act like proverbial bulls in a china shop? My fear of pointless end-of-life treatments, performed while I was in no condition to reject them, escalated when I read Dr. Jessica Nutik Zitters book, Extreme Measures: Finding a Better Path to the End of Life.

title: New York Today: Free College, but With Caveats
description: Updated, 7:56 a.m.

title: Morning Agenda: Wall Street in the White House
description: President Trump described the Chinese as the world champions of currency manipulation.

title: Get Out, S-Town and What to Do With Our Racial Past
description: It has been less than a month since the podcast S-Town arrived, and in that time it has become a juggernaut, with millions and millions of downloads and buckets of praise. The show comes from the people behind This American Life and Serial, which had previously broken download records. In S-Town, theres a clever bait-and-switch. Come for the promise of a murder mystery and a treasure hunt. Stay for the X-ray of a rural Alabama county and its most colorful resident, John B. McLemore.

title: Lesley Stahl: By the Book
description: The journalist and author of Becoming Grandma says Ann Patchetts Bel Canto reminded her of Gabriel Garca Mrquez, a high compliment: My all-time favorite book . . . is Love in the Time of Cholera.

title: A Transgender Learning Gap in the Emergency Room
description: As an emergency physician, Im always engaging in a fast-tempo, often awkward, all too stressful dance with strangers. Lately, though, Ive noticed a particular gap in my own medical education and training, as well as in that of my colleagues, thats further tripping up our steps: how to provide optimal health care for transgender patients.

title: Thanks for Your Service, Pothole Warrior
description: I am a little on edge because I have been to the Pothole Wars and soon I will have to go back. This is just a short-term PTSD leave after I was ambushed at the Manhattan entrance to the George Washington Bridge last week. I should have seen it coming (it is, after all pothole season) but it was a tight merge, in heavy traffic, and by the time I saw the pothole, I was in it.

title: 1967: U.K. to Defy Spain on Gibraltar Flights
description: LONDON  Britain declared today it will defy any attempts by Spain to prevent aircraft from using Gibraltar and called a temporary halt to negotiations with Madrid over the dispute.

title: Movers: Paulson Leaves A.I.G. Board and Banks Report Earnings
description: Were following major developments in the markets throughout the day. Check below for the latest updates.

title: A Checklist for Inspection of Jails
description: Jails around the country seeking to house detained immigrants must meet the requirements of a inspection checklist.

title: European Court Faults Russias Handling of 2004 Beslan School Siege
description: LONDON  The Russian authorities ignored warnings of an impending terrorist attack and then violated European human rights law when they stormed a school seized by Chechen militants in September 2004, resulting in the deaths of more than 330 hostages, a court ruled on Thursday.

title: Trump Plan Would Curtail Protections for Detained Immigrants
description: For more than 15 years, jails that hold immigrants facing deportation have had to follow a growing list of requirements:

title: Knicks vs. 76ers: A Battle of Losing Philosophies
description: On the burnt end of the N.B.A. season, an unintentional loser beat an intentional loser.

title: California Today: The Allure of the Los Angeles Car Chase
description: Good morning.

title: Lawyers for Women in Kim Jong-nam Case Say They Were Scapegoated
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia  The two women who claim they were tricked into assassinating the estranged half brother of North Koreas leader appeared in court Thursday, where their lawyers argued that Malaysias decision to free three North Korean suspects ended any chance of bringing the real culprits to justice.

title: Kosovo Feels Russias Heavy Hand, via Serbia
description: PRISTINA, Kosovo  For centuries, dark forces of history have found the Balkans a suitable proxy region for unleashing grand plans for global prominence and competition. Now, after two decades of stability and prospects for a prosperous future, Serbia again is returning to an old vocation  seeking regional hegemony. It is doing so by destabilizing the Balkans, expanding its own military and working toward economic dominance of a regional common market that Kosovo finds unacceptable and strongly opposes  all of this with Russia looking over Serbias shoulder.

title: Cannes Film Festival Announces 2017 Lineup
description: New films by Sofia Coppola, Noah Baumbach, Todd Haynes, Michael Haneke and Michel Hazanavicius will be among the competitors for the Palme dOr at the 70th Cannes Film Festival next month, the festival announced on Thursday.

title: N.B.A. Playoffs 2017: Who We Think Will Win
description: Ever since Kyrie Irvings 3-pointer sailed over Stephen Currys outstretched arms and through the basket in the waning moments of Game 7 of last years N.B.A. finals, serving as a dagger to finish off one of the greatest comebacks in the history of sports, there has been an inevitability about another finals rematch between the Cleveland Cavaliers and the Golden State Warriors.

title: City Ballet Season to Feature Jerome Robbins Celebration
description: New York City Ballet is usually the house of George Balanchine. But for its 2017-18 season, the company announced Thursday, it will make ample room for its other founding choreographer, Jerome Robbins, for the centennial of his birth. The tribute, Robbins 100, will feature 19 of his ballets.

title: China Says Its Trade With North Korea Has Increased
description: BEIJING  Amid sharply rising tensions over North Koreas nuclear arms program, China said on Thursday that its trade with the country had expanded, even though it had complied with United Nations sanctions and stopped buying North Korean coal, a major source of hard currency for Pyongyang.

title: In Sports, Boston Is Now Second to None
description: Its a good time to be a Boston sports fan.

title: After a Sopranos Crisis, a Brnnhilde Is Born
description: TORONTO  She had just immolated herself onstage in one of the most demanding roles in opera: Brnnhilde, the Valkyrie who becomes mortal and redeems the world in Wagners epic Ring cycle.

title: 18 Syrian Fighters Allied With U.S. Are Killed in Coalition Airstrike
description: WASHINGTON  An airstrike by the American-led coalition fighting the Islamic State killed 18 Syrian fighters allied with the United States, the military said on Thursday.

title: When You Know Its Love: Her Lyrics Move You
description: How do you know when you are in love? No 1-800-line psychic will tell you. No notice sent by registered mail. Not even a ping from your iPhone. But there are a million ways of figuring it out, and weve asked some people when they knew. Here is one way:

title: How Survivor and CBS Prepared for Outrage at Transgender Contestants Outing
description: At first blush, it looks like a crisis for CBS: broadcasting an episode of its hit reality show Survivor on Wednesday in which one contestant outs a rival as transgender during an elimination round  a violation of privacy as well as a cultural flash point.

title: Unsettled by a Sex Tape Request
description: Ive been dating my boyfriend for six years. We are in our 40s. Early on, we made some sex videos. They werent porn; they were cute and captured how much in love we were. Im glad we did them. But lately, he wants to push our boundaries, while were still young enough, he says. He would like a friend to film us having sex. I want to make him happy, and maybe it would be fun, but I cant get my head around it. Should I try this, or tell him to forget it?

title: Inside Turkeys Purge
description: The police officers came to the doctors door in Istanbul at 6 a.m.  dawn raids usually start then, sometimes 5:30  and one of them said, You are accused of attempting to kill President Erdogan.

title: Dancing Balanchine: Like Being the Most Abstract Piece of Art
Mystery and Melancholy Surround Death of Judge Found in the Hudson
description: The last time someone heard from Judge Sheila Abdus-Salaam apparently was on Tuesday when she called her chambers in the Graybar Building in Manhattan to say she wasnt well and would not be coming in. At some point, she had left her apartment in Harlem, law enforcement officials said, departing without her wallet and cellphone, and locking the door behind her.

title: Trumps Previous View of NATO Is Now Obsolete
description: WASHINGTON  As a candidate, President Trump disparaged NATO as a musty relic of old thinking, an alliance focused on long-gone adversaries rather than new-era threats, a burden that drained American resources on behalf of ungrateful partners who did not pay their share. In a word: obsolete.

title: Inside a Larger-Than-Life Art Installation in Virtual Reality
description: The groundbreaking artist Taryn Simon blends sculpture, sound, architecture and performance in An Occupation of Loss, her provocative piece exploring the anatomy of grief.

title: A Mini-Met Mashup on the Museums Roof, With Summer Views
description: Two pitfalls lie in wait for artists who win the prestigious commission to create works for the rooftop of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The obvious risk is the view, onto Central Park and the skylines of Midtown and the West Side, that can minimize or overshadow the art on display. (Cornelia Parker, the British sculptor who erected a Hitchcockian house facade, fell into that trap last year.) The other, stealthier risk is the museum below. When you are literally standing on top of five millenniums of art history, even the most assured artist can be spooked.

title: Ecuadoreans Have the Right to a Recount
description: QUITO, Ecuador  The people  hundreds and thousands of them  took to the streets to peacefully demand a recount of the votes. Many Ecuadoreans simply did not believe the announcement of the results of the April 2 election, which gave the victory to the ruling partys candidate, Lenin Moreno, with 51.15 percent of the vote, and said Guillermo Lasso, the Creo-Suma party candidate, received 48.85 percent.

title: A Virtual Tour of a Larger-Than-Life Art Installation
description: Immerse yourself in a 360-degree experience directed by Luca Guadagnino, best viewed on a smartphone with a Google Cardboard or a Daydream View.

title: A Win Over Sexism in Brazil: A Soap Star Is Punished for Harassment
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  It could have been the plot of one of Brazils hugely popular nighttime soap operas.

title: An Impeached President, Reeling but Defiant
description: Nearly a year ago, Brazilian lawmakers voted to suspend President Dilma Rousseff from office, setting in motion the dramatic downfall of the countrys first female leader. Ms. Rousseff, a former guerrilla leader who was tortured during the countrys military dictatorship in the 1970s, was formally ousted last September. Her removal marked the end of a 13-year period of rule by the leftist Workers Party and a seismic shift in the countrys political trajectory. I interviewed Ms. Rousseff last weekend at the Brazil Conference at Harvard and M.I.T., during which she delivered a defiant speech warning that Brazils democracy is in peril. Below is a lightly edited excerpt of our conversation.

title: Do Your Shoelaces Keep Coming Undone? Engineers Explain Why
description: Researchers at the University of California, Berkeley, have unraveled one of lifes enduring mysteries: Why do shoelaces come undone?

title: Vegas Golden Knights, N.H.L. Expansion Team, Hire Head Coach
description: Five months before they open their inaugural training camp, the Vegas Golden Knights introduced Gerard Gallant as their first head coach on Thursday.

title: Marathons: An Especially Bad Day for a Heart Attack
description: Road closings during marathons can be frustrating for drivers and pedestrians. Now a new study suggests they can be bad for your health.

title: Yankees Abundance of Caution With Young Arms Is Not Enough
description: When the Yankees had the 16th overall pick in the 2015 draft, their highest selection since they had taken Derek Jeter with the sixth pick in 1993, there was a tantalizing prospect still on the board.

title: Four Bodies Found on Long Island Appear Linked to Gang Violence
description: CENTRAL ISLIP, N.Y.  The phone call came Wednesday night, delivering ominous words in an area of Long Island torn apart by gang violence.

title: Send Some Sass With That Text Message
description: Q. On my iPhone, I recently got an iMessage from a friend who had an animation of confetti playing in the background screen. How is this done?

title: Trudeau Unveils Bill Legalizing Recreational Marijuana in Canada
description: OTTAWA  Fulfilling a campaign pledge, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau introduced legislation on Thursday to legalize the recreational use of marijuana in Canada.

title: Exposing Russian Disinformation Since the 1950s
description: It was Eva who first noticed that the disinformation starts the minute you land on any Aeroflot flight in Moscow.

title: U.N. Experts Condemn Killing and Torture of Gay Men in Chechnya
description: LONDON  United Nations experts demanded on Thursday that Chechnya halt the abduction, detention, beating and killing of gay and bisexual men, after weeks of reports about violent repression there.

title: Inside a Dark Alley With the Fashion Critic Vanessa Friedman
description: The email arrived from Louis Vuitton just before Paris Fashion Week: Did I want to sneak away between shows to see a supersecret project the brand had been working on with an unnamed partner? Of course I did.

title: Online Upstarts Seek to Disrupt Used-Car Buying
description: Emily Hurwitz, an advertising supervisor who lives in San Francisco, doesnt like buying cars from traditional dealerships. In fact, she recently bought a 2012 Volkswagen Tiguan through Shift, a start-up that arranges online sales of used cars. She is happy with her car, which the company brought directly to her apartment to try out. Shift financed the $18,000 vehicle.

title: Tech Roundup: Paying Up to $500 to Chat With a Live Streamer
description: YouTube has been a source of many videos and memes that have wound their way into popular culture. Now the Google-owned video site may increasingly be a source of ideas for how to make more money online, too.

title: Assad Says Videos of Dead Children in Syria Chemical Attack Were Faked
description: Vilified by accusations of using a chemical bomb, Syrias president intensified his counterpropaganda campaign on Thursday, suggesting that child actors had staged death scenes to malign him and that American warplanes had bombed a terrorist warehouse full of poison gases, killing hundreds of people.

title: United Airlines Passenger May Need Surgery, Lawyer Says
description: CHICAGO  In an hourlong news conference that touched on race, policing and airline manners, a lawyer for the passenger dragged off a United flight on Sunday listed his clients injuries: a broken nose, a concussion, two knocked-out teeth and sinus problems that may require reconstructive surgery.

title: Review: A Quiet Passion Poetically Captures Emily Dickinson
description: New England in the mid-19th century was a literary hothouse, overgrown with wild and exotic talents. That Emily Dickinson was among the most dazzling of these is not disputable, but to say that she was obscure in her own time would exaggerate her celebrity. A handful of her poems appeared in print while she was alive (she died in 1886, at 55), but she preferred private rituals of publication, carefully writing out her verses and sewing them into booklets.

title: Iraqi Held After Borussia Dortmund Attack Is Suspected of ISIS Ties
description: BERLIN  An Iraqi who was detained after the bombing of a soccer team bus in Dortmund is suspected of having led an Islamic State unit before fleeing to Germany last year, the federal prosecutor said Thursday.

title: New Tools Needed to Track Technologys Impact on Jobs, Panel Says
description: America needs new tools for the timely measurement and monitoring of technology, jobs and skills to cope with the advance of artificial intelligence and automation, an expert panel composed mainly of economists and computer scientists said in a new report.

title: For the Love of Dance, a Collection to Match
description: On a recent afternoon, with wind and rain lashing against the windows of her apartment on Central Park West, Patsy Tarr stood in her dining room surrounded by a few of her favorite artworks by Robert Rauschenberg, Roy Lichtenstein and Donald Judd. A photograph of Merce Cunningham by Barbara Morgan hung nearby, and an Alexander Calder mobile dangled over the table. If we open the windows, she said, it actually spins around.

title: The Creators: Rob Pruitt
description: Inside the day of the provocative contemporary artist, as he meditates on the lawn of his apartment building, shops at Ikea and works in his studio.

title: Officers Confrontation With a Pedestrian, Caught on Video, Spurs Investigations
description: It began innocuously enough.

title: Britains Uneasy Labor Market
description: Britains job market is thriving, and unemployment is at its lowest level since 1975. But this is, technically,only the beginning of theBrexit era. The full effects of the countrys increasingly contentious divorce from the European Union are still in the distance.

title: Social Media Is Not Contributing Significantly to Political Polarization, Paper Says
description: Why has the United States become so politically polarized?

title: Trinity Church Is Sued for Moving a Sculpture That Marked the 9/11 Loss of a Tree
description: A sculptor is suing Trinity Church in Lower Manhattan for moving his bronze re-creation of a huge sycamore tree that once stood in the churchyard.

title: Plumes From Saturns Moon Enceladus Hint That It Could Support Life
description: Could icy moons like Saturns Enceladus in the outer solar system be home to microbes or other forms of alien life?

title: Trump Signs Law Taking Aim at Planned Parenthood Funding
description: WASHINGTON  President Trump signed legislation on Thursday aimed at cutting off federal funding to Planned Parenthood and other groups that perform abortions, a move cheered by conservatives who have clamored to impose curbs on reproductive rights.

title: Will London Fall? How Dare You!
description: Will London fall?

title: U.S. Drops Mother of All Bombs on ISIS Caves in Afghanistan
description: WASHINGTON  The United States dropped the mother of all bombs  the most powerful conventional bomb in the American arsenal  on an Islamic State cave complex in Afghanistan on Thursday, the Pentagon said, unleashing a weapon so massive that it had to be dropped from the rear of a cargo plane.

title: A Star Wars Salvo in the Toy-Store Gender Wars
description: LOS ANGELES  Disney on Thursday unveiled a series of animated shorts and related merchandise billed as celebrating the inspiring stories of iconic heroes from across the Star Wars universe.

title: Wafas Express
description: A beloved Lebanese chef returns to the kitchen in this takeout spot in East Williamsburg, Brooklyn.

title: The Smoky Allure of Lebanon Wafts Through Wafas Express
description: All afternoon the scent followed me, smoke rising off roasting meat, and rose water like a balm thumbed behind the ears: the perfume of Wafas Express in East Williamsburg, Brooklyn.

title: Can Churches Hire Police? Alabama Legislators Reckon With the First Amendment
description: To what lengths can a church go to protect its flock?

title: Investment in the Maldives
description: To the Editor:

title: Ford Foundation Is an Unlikely Convert to Impact Investing
description: Peter A. Nadosy is a pillar of the Wall Street establishment  he spent 27 years at Morgan Stanley, rising to vice chairman. He served a stint managing the endowment at Harvard, his alma mater, and hes also a life trustee and member of the investment committee at Amherst College. Hes on multiple boards of nonprofit institutions, including the Doris Duke Charitable Foundation and St. Andrews Dune Church in Southampton, N.Y.

title: Sifting Through S.U.V.s to Find the Best
description: S.U.V.s and crossovers have the reputation of being a bit boring with staid designs, but several models stand out from the utilitarian crowd.

title: Video Review: Favorite S.U.V.s, From Most Affordable to Luxurious
description: While Americans have not taken up camping or off-roading at a prodigious rate, S.U.V.s have become the vehicles of choice in the United States. The appeal is in the rugged look, a high seating position and a knack for swallowing cargo.

title: Review: In Showtimes Guerrilla, Radicalism Without the Mythology
description: John Ridley has already made some ambitious television, and hes at it again with Guerrilla, a microstudy of radicalism in Britain in the early 1970s.

title: U.N. Votes Unanimously to End Peacekeeping Mission in Haiti
description: UNITED NATIONS  The United Nations Security Council voted unanimously on Thursday to end its 13-year-long peacekeeping mission in Haiti, and replace its blue-helmeted soldiers with police officers.

title: When in Rome ... Yes, You Can Have Rice on Passover
description: ROME  This has not been a banner couple of years for being home for the holidays.

title: Blue Jackets Cam Atkinson Rebukes Naysayers With Standout Season
description: It was well past bedtime at Avon Old Farms, a prestigious all-boys boarding school with Cotswolds-style buildings seemingly straight out of a Harry Potter book, but the night was still young for Cam Atkinson. A promising hockey prospect from 90 minutes down the road in the Riverside section of Greenwich, Conn., Atkinson knew the trick to unlocking one of the back doors to the on-campus rink, where anywhere from five to 15 students often congregated after curfew for a pickup game on the dimly lit ice.

title: France and the Holocaust
description: To the Editor:

title: Afghanistan, Syria, Beslan: Your Morning Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: A Spur Takes His Game (and Flannel Shirts) to the TV Studio
description: SAN ANTONIO  Matt Bonner prepared for his new gig by rummaging through his closet. He found 19 flannel shirts and seven pairs of corduroy pants. Based on his calculations, he had nearly 150 wardrobe combinations  more than enough to last an entire season.

title: Trumps Sole Objective
description: To the Editor:

title: Silver Fish Surf the Waves to Spawn on California Beaches
description: Every year, thousands of little fish ride waves onto Southern Californias beaches at night to lay and fertilize eggs. High up in the sand, they squirm, wriggle and wrap around one another. As they dance beneath the moonlight, the beach transforms into a twinkling tapestry of spawning silver bodies. Its known as the grunion run, and within a few hours, the show is over.

title: The Unreasonable Genius of Russell Westbrook
description: The N.B.A.s regular season ended last night, which means that we can now say it officially: Russell Westbrook is not just an unreasonable maniac  he is an unreasonable maniac of historic proportions. His insanity is now immortal. Back at the seasons halfway point, I wrote a profile of Westbrook and his quest to achieve one of basketballs sacred feats: to average a triple-double for an entire season. (A triple-double means registering, in one game, double digits in three different statistics, usually points, rebounds and assists.) This had happened only once in N.B.A. history, in 1962, and it seemed unlikely to ever happen again. Averaging a triple-double, I wrote, is like having a helicopter that is also a boat that can also write the Great American Novel; if Westbrook managed to pull it off, it would be not only historic and impressive but also a little weird, almost disturbing.

title: The Evangelical Roots of Our Post-Truth Society
description: THE arrival of the post-truth political climate came as a shock to many Americans. But to the Christian writer Rachel Held Evans, charges of fake news are nothing new. The deep distrust of the media, of scientific consensus  those were prevalent narratives growing up, she told me.

title: Khmer Rouge Tribunal: A U.N. Prosecutors View
description: To the Editor:

title: Ways to Resist Trump
description: To the Editor:

title: 11 New Books We Recommend This Week
description: Poetry / can be / the magic / carpet, writes Bill Knott, and the exhilarating ride provided by his selected poems, I Am Flying Into Myself, would appear to prove it. New voices on our radar this week include Stephanie Powell Watts, whose moving update of The Great Gatsby features an African-American family in a declining North Carolina town, and Vivek Shanbhag, whose novella Ghachar Ghochar comes lauded as one of the finest works of Indian fiction in a decade. Fans of Mary Gaitskills fiction (Bad Behavior, Veronica, The Mare) will welcome her essay collection Somebody With a Little Hammer. And a courageous book by Ron Powers delves into his familys struggles with schizophrenia in service of a larger goal: to arm other families with a sense of urgency that perhaps came to us too late.

title: Hey, New York Film Lovers, Another Art House Is (Back) on the Scene
description: The art-house revival continues in New York this week with the return of the citys first four-screen movie theater. The Quad Cinema, which opened in Greenwich Village in 1972, has received a modern makeover from a movie-loving entrepreneur.

title: A New Museum of the American Revolution, Warts and All
description: PHILADELPHIA  The new Museum of the American Revolution, which opens here on Wednesday, stands on the site of a defunct welcome center built for the Bicentennial.

title: Its Like It Never Left: Another El Nio May Be on the Way
description: Less than a year after one of the strongest El Nios on record, forecasters see an increasing possibility that another will begin later this year.

title: What to See in New York Art Galleries This Week
description: Through April 23. Swiss Institute, 102 Franklin Street, Manhattan; 212-925-2035, swissinstitute.net.

title: Should Fearless Girl Statue Stay or Go? Readers Debate Arts Meaning
description: The sculptor of the Charging Bull statue near Wall Street wants the facing Fearless Girl sculpture to go away, saying that the original meaning of the bronze bull  freedom, peace, strength, power and love  has been lost. The artist, Arturo Di Modica, said his statues message had become negative with her there.

title: Paperback Row
description: AMERICAN HEIRESS: The Wild Saga of the Kidnapping, Crimes and Trial of Patty Hearst, by Jeffrey Toobin. (Anchor, $16.95.) This captivating account traces Hearsts kidnapping in 1974, from her collusion with her captors to her jail time, and the media spectacle surrounding it. Toobin offers legal expertise and an empathetic eye; even members of the Symbionese Liberation Army are shown some compassion.

title: Review: Heal the Living, a Sentimental Sales Pitch for Organ Donation
description: If you have ever been moved to tears by a television commercial, then prepare to be devastated by Heal the Living, one of the most gorgeous and beautifully acted sales pitches you are ever likely to encounter. What youre being asked to buy, however, is not cereal or sugary soda; no, this juggernaut of sentiment  whether intentionally or not  plays like nothing so much as a hugely expensive advertisement for organ donation.

title: Whats New in NYC Theater
description: Our guide to plays and musicals coming to New York stages  and a few last-chance picks of shows that are about to close. Our reviews of open shows are at nytimes.com/reviews/theater.

title: Charging Bull vs. Fearless Girl
description: To the Editor:

title: At MoMA, Women at Play in the Fields of Abstraction
description: Funnily enough, the Museum of Modern Art has never named the long-running blockbuster show that fills its permanent-collection galleries. So Ill name it: Modern White Guys: The Greatest Art Story Ever Invented. What the museum does name are the occasional temporary exhibitions that offer an alternative to that story. Making Space: Women Artists and Postwar Abstraction is the latest, and a stimulating alternative it is.

title: Silos, Sulfur and Stolen Identities: The Best of New Crime Fiction
description: Sara Paretsky defies the old notion that regional detectives dont travel well outside their home turf. In FALLOUT (Morrow/HarperCollins, $27.99), her Chicago private eye, V. I. Warshawski, goes on a solo road trip to Kansas (where Paretsky was born and raised) with her dog, Peppy, for company and her red Bruno Magli pumps, just in case a tornado carries her off to the land of Oz.

title: In This Tale of Online Intimacy, the Only Wise Characters Are Luddites
description: SYMPATHY  By Olivia Sudjic406 pp. Houghton Mifflin Harcourt. $25.

title: Review: Hearts of Darkness and Light in The Lost City of Z
description: In The Lost City of Z, a lush, melancholic story of discovery and mystery, a mesmerizing Charlie Hunnam plays a British adventurer in the Amazon who is consumed by all the glories of exploration, as Joseph Conrad once wrote of a different journey. Enveloped by the forest, the explorer and his crew face snakes, piranhas, insects and that most terrifying of threats: other people, who at times bombard the strangers with arrows. Undaunted, he perseveres, venturing more deeply into a world that first becomes a passion and then something of a private hallucination. Its 1906, and while wonders like moving pictures are rapidly shrinking the world, the dream of unknown lands endures.

title: Pop, Rock and Jazz in NYC This Week
description: Our guide to pop and rock shows and the best of live jazz.

title: Listen to Es ist vollbracht
description: Avery Amereau performs this aria from St. John Passion

title: In Praise of Agatha Christies Accidental Sleuths
description: The Enthusiast is an occasional column dedicated to the books we love to read and reread.

title: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
description: No matter how much free time you have this weekend, we have TV recommendations for you. Come back every Friday for new suggestions from our TV critic on what to watch.

title: Listen to Wer hat dich so geschlagen
description: Tenet performs this chorale from St. John Passion

title: Joan See, Who Acted in TV Ads and Helped Others Do That, Dies at 83
description: Joan See, an actress who capitalized on her success in television commercials by creating a school to teach others how to do the same, died on April 5 in Jersey City. She was 83.

title: Anatomy of a Scene | The Fate of the Furious
description: F. Gary Gray narrates a sequence from his film featuring Vin Diesel and Celestino Cornielle.

title: Classical Music in NYC This Week
description: Our guide to the citys best classical music and opera.

title: Review: All These Sleepless Nights Roams the Streets of Warsaw
description: As the Warsaw-set All These Sleepless Nights begins, the protagonist, Kris (Krzysztof Baginski), relates some unattributed wisdom. He has heard that if you tallied a lifetimes experiences, you would get seven months of sex, 17 hours of breakups and 51 days of deciding what to wear.

title: Review: A Fragmented Past in By the Time It Gets Dark
description: By the Time It Gets Dark, the second feature from the Thai director Anocha Suwichakornpong, tiptoes around an event in October 1976, when students at Thammasat University in Bangkok were violently suppressed while protesting the return of a military leader.

title: Comedy in NYC This Week
description: Our guide to stand-up, improv and variety shows.

title: Review: In Chasing Trane, Wheres the Joy of Sax?
description: Chasing Trane: The John Coltrane Documentary portrays the legendary saxophonist as a tirelessly forward-thinking artist. (His music, the philosopher Cornel West says in the film, was more of a thermostat than a thermometer.) But as a biographical movie, Chasing Trane sticks to a conventional, dully informative format. Its ideal venue is a Coltrane tribute event or a classroom.

title: Review: Finding Oscar, and Hope, in Massacres Aftermath
description: The barbarity described in Finding Oscar is stomach-turning, but moments of courage still shine through in this unsettling yet vital documentary.

title: Review: In Little Boxes, a Biracial Family Meets a White Town
description: Little Boxes, a mildly comic story about a biracial family that relocates to an exceedingly white town, feels a bit out of phase, but its delicately observed and does a nice job of staying within itself. It avoids the big confrontation or grand statement; doing so allows it to be an effective, if somewhat uneventful, study of the Brooklyn bubble effect.

title: Review: Maurizio Cattelan: Be Right Back Relishes a Mischievous Artist
description: I think hes one of the greatest artists that we have today  but he could also be the worst, a collector says in Maurizio Cattelan: Be Right Back. Its one of several bits of hyperbole in a documentary that works best when it stops overanalyzing its subject and instead focuses on his mischievous art.

title: Cubs Fans Waited 108 Years. Cooperstown Is Still Waiting.
description: CHICAGO  The Chicago Cubs were baseballs biggest story last season, winning their first World Series title in more than a century, and now they have the banner and the rings to prove it. What the 2016 champions do not have  at least not yet  is a presence at the sports Hall of Fame in Cooperstown, N.Y.

title: Dance in NYC This Week
description: Our guide to dance performances.

title: Review: In Mimosas, a Cryptic Mountain Trek
description: At best ambiguous and at worst unfathomable, Mimosas, the sophomore feature from the Spanish director Oliver Laxe, merges harsh reality and offbeat mysticism into a reflection on the tug between our higher powers and baser instincts.

title: Review: Angst, Jealousy and My Entire High School Sinking Into the Sea
description: Hot on the heels of The Death of Louis XIV comes another candidate for Most Accurately Titled Film of 2017. Tenderhearted readers, fear not; this is neither a documentary nor a live-action depiction. My Entire High School Sinking Into the Sea, written and directed by Dash Shaw, is an eccentric and lively animated fantasy.

title: Steelers Chairman Dan Rooney, 84, Dies; N.F.L. Force and Link to Footballs Past
description: Dan Rooney, the longtime Pittsburgh Steelers chairman who helped shape the modern National Football League and was one of the last surviving links to its founders, died on Thursday in Pittsburgh. He was 84.

title: Review: In Tommys Honour, a Family Feud on and Off the Green
description: Redolent of damp wool and dour personalities, Tommys Honour wants to convince us that watching two men bicker and bang balls into tiny holes for the better part of two hours is the height of entertainment.

title: Film Series in NYC This Week
description: Our guide to film series and special screenings. All our movie reviews are at nytimes.com/reviews/movies.

title: Liberty House and the Shifting Focus of Political Style
description: Should You Dress for Resistance at New York Fashion Week?

title: Afghanistan, United Airlines, Syria: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Art and Museums in NYC This Week
description: Our guide to new art shows  and some that will be closing soon.

title: Those Huddled Masses: Were They in New Jersey, or New York?
description: Q. I always thought Ellis Island was a part of New York, but my friend says its in New Jersey. Whos right?

title: Estate of Tech Entrepreneur Who Invented an Anti-Theft Tag Lists for $8.5 Million
description: The estate of George Lichtblau, an entrepreneur best known for inventing the anti-shoplifting tags attached to clothing in stores, sits on a majestic perch on 8.4 acres overlooking a large pond in New Canaan, Conn.

title: Events for Children in NYC This Week
description: Our guide to cultural events in New York City for families with children and teenagers.

title: A Sisterhood of Scares
description: SHARONVILLE, Ohio  Like heavy metal or Wall Street, horror can seem like a boys club. Men make the movies. Women play the victims.

title: The Legal Battle Over Arkansas Execution Plans
description: Death row inmates have argued that the states rushed execution schedule and the use of the drug midazolam are unconstitutional.

title: Trumps Policy Reversals, in His Own Words
description: President Trump has reversed himself on several longstanding positions over the past week.

title: This Weeks Movies: April 14, 2017
description: The New York Times film critics review The Fate of the Furious, The Lost City of Z and Norman."

title: No Environmental Impact Study? No Border Wall, Lawsuit Says
description: PHOENIX  An environmental group and an Arizona congressman have sued to block the construction of President Trumps wall along the southern border, threatening to derail one of his marquee projects well before it gets off the ground.

title: How Destructive Is the Mother of All Bombs?
description: The United States dropped the most powerful nonnuclear bomb in its arsenal on what it said was an ISIS cave complex in remote Afghanistan. The bomb  called the GBU-43/B Massive Ordnance Air Blast  can obliterate everything within a 1,000-yard radius.

title: Workers Find Winning a Wage Judgment Can Be an Empty Victory
description: The sign above Soft Touch Car Wash on Broadway in the Inwood neighborhood of Manhattan declares, Open 24 hours, but last month the bustling carwash suddenly closed. It was the same at the four other carwashes owned by the same family in New York City and the surrounding area: the phone lines disconnected, the hoses and wash mops idle and dry.

title: Fire Tears Through Senegal Religious Festival, Killing at Least 22
description: DAKAR, Senegal  A fire that erupted during a religious festival in rural Senegal attended by thousands of people has killed at least 22 worshipers and injured more than 100, government officials said.

title: After Season of Silence, Phil Jackson Is to Address Local News Media
description: In the 202 days since Phil Jackson last spoke to members of the local news media who regularly cover the Knicks, the team has lost 51 games; a former franchise bulwark, Charles Oakley, was arrested after a courtside quarrel; two off-season acquisitions, Derrick Rose and Joakim Noah, have sustained season-ending injuries; and Jackson, the team president, has used Twitter to take shots at his star player, Carmelo Anthony.

title: Bill OReillys World: Books, Philanthropy and Speaking Engagements
description: Bill OReilly is both an ambassador and a moneymaker for Fox News, his television home since 1996. His show, The OReilly Factor, which airs at 8 on weeknights, is routinely the highest-ranked show on cable news. And his blend of I-know-best commentary and pointed interviews established a genre of opinion programming that has come to dominate much of television news.

title: Secret Service Fires Two Officers Over White House Fence-Jumping Episode
description: WASHINGTON  The Secret Service has fired two officers from its uniformed division who were on duty when a California man jumped the White House fence last month and roamed the grounds for 17 minutes, an agency official confirmed on Thursday.

title: Trump Organization Drops Plans for Dallas Hotel With Turkish Trump
description: The Trump Organization said on Thursday it had rejected a proposed Dallas hotel project with a real estate firm that had attracted scrutiny for its vast foreign ties to Russia, Kazakhstan and at least two dozen other countries.

title: Overseas Adoptions by Americans Continue to Decline
description: They have spent thousands of dollars in fees, scaled a mountain of paperwork and waited nearly five years, but Caroline and Jason Lankford have yet to be matched with the Ethiopian child they long to adopt.

title: A Stranger in the Building on Official Business
description: Dear Diary:

title: Bob Cerv, Three-Time Yankee and One-Time All-Star, Dies at 91
description: Bob Cervs desire to play for the Yankees was roused by a trip to New York with his father, who drove a refrigerated food truck from Nebraska. He was only 11 or 12, but seeing Lou Gehrig hit home runs at Yankee Stadium made him want to play there as well.

title: Michigan Doctor Is Accused of Genital Cutting of 2 Girls
description: A Michigan doctor has been accused of performing genital cutting on two 7-year-old girls at a medical clinic, in a case that federal officials believe to be the first prosecution under a law banning the brutal practice.

title: Jeff Sessions, Unleashed at the Border
description: Attorney General Jeff Sessions went to the border in Arizona on Tuesday and declared it a hellscape, a ground zero of death and violence where Americans must take our stand against a tide of evil flooding up from Mexico.

title: Quotation of the Day: Only Thing Different About NATO Is Presidents Opinion of It
description: Nothing has changed at NATO in the last 80 days. Its gratifying to see the president affirming that NATO is no longer obsolete  it never was.

title: Mike Pompeo, Once a WikiLeaks Fan, Attacks It as Hostile Agent
description: WASHINGTON  In his first speech as director of the Central Intelligence Agency, Mike Pompeo, the former Republican congressman who once applauded disclosures by WikiLeaks, attacked the group on Thursday as a stateless hostile intelligence unit eager to do the bidding of Russia and other American adversaries.

title: St. Jude Medical Played Down Defibrillator Failures for Years, F.D.A. Says
description: The medical device maker St. Jude Medical played down the failure of some batteries in its defibrillators, shipping them for years before recalling the devices last fall, according to a warning letter the Food and Drug Administration issued this week.

title: Kelsey Plum Is a Lot Like James Harden. But Is It a Left-Handed Compliment?
description: As Kelsey Plum neared the N.C.A.A. womens basketball career scoring record during her senior season at the University of Washington, her game became equated with that of another prolific left-handed shooter.

title: Report to the Board of Trustees of Choate Rosemary Hall
description: Written by an investigator at the law firm Covington & Burling LLP, the report documented the actions of at least 12 former faculty members, beginning in the 1960s and into the 2010s

title: Sexual Abuse at Choate Went On for Decades, School Acknowledges
description: Choate Rosemary Hall, the elite Connecticut boarding school, said on Thursday that at least 12 former teachers had sexually molested  and, in at least one case, raped  students in a pattern of abuse dating to the 1960s.

title: Corrections: April 14, 2017
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Latest Series Against Cubs Reminds Dodgers of World Series Drought
description: CHICAGO  The cruelty of the schedule was clear to the Los Angeles Dodgers. Their new second baseman, Logan Forsythe, noticed at spring training that his teammates were buzzing about it. Of all teams, they would be the guests when the Chicago Cubs raised their World Series championship flag at Wrigley Field. The Dodgers season had ended here last fall when the Cubs stormed past them on their way to glory.

title: United and Pepsi Affairs Force Brands to Respect Social Media
description: When Jason Marker, the new chief executive of the company that owns Carls Jr. and Hardees, met with several of his marketing executives this week, one of his first requests was for screens to be installed in the companys headquarters to display real-time social media conversations about its brands.

title: Trump Threatens Health Subsidies to Force Democrats to Bargain
description: WASHINGTON  In the weeks since President Trumps attempts to replace the Affordable Care Act collapsed, the administration has debated what to do: Try again? Shore up the insurance marketplaces? Or let the whole system collapse?

title: Bank Lending Stalls on Doubts About Trumps Pro-Growth Agenda
description: Many business owners and corporate executives have expressed unbridled optimism that President Trump can fuel economic growth and increase their profits.

title: For Trump, a Steep Learning Curve Leads to Policy Reversals
description: WASHINGTON  For President Trump, the road to changing his mind on China included a discussion with corporate executives in the State Dining Room of the White House in February. When the conversation turned to Chinas currency, the executives had a simple message for the president: Youre wrong.

title: A Boys Life Is Lost to Sepsis. Thousands Are Saved in His Wake.
description: A note arrived, asking about a subject that was covered here five years ago.

title: Floor Support
description: FRIDAY PUZZLE  In the span of nearly a year, Andrew Kingsley has made his New York Times Crossword debut and managed to have six puzzles published here. This is lucky No. 7, and its a nice way to start our solving weekend.

title: Review: Oslo Fills a Large Canvas in a Thrilling Production
description: Some works of art cry out for large canvases. Though it is sparing in its use of scenery or anything approaching spectacle, J. T. Rogerss Oslo, an against-the-odds story of international peacemaking, is undeniably a big play, as expansive and ambitious as any in recent Broadway history. So it is particularly gratifying to announce that it has been allowed to stretch to its full height in the thrilling production that opened on Thursday night, directed with a masters hand by Bartlett Sher.

title: G.M. Expands Self-Driving Car Operations in Silicon Valley
description: In the race to develop self-driving cars, General Motors is expanding its operations near Silicon Valley.

title: San Diego Mogul, Seeking Residence for Mayors Race, Says He Finds Bias
description: Roque De La Fuente, a millionaire San Diego developer who ran unsuccessfully for president last year, would now like to be mayor of New York City. But he has already failed to win over a much smaller constituency: the co-op board of a Fifth Avenue building that rejected his $1.28 million offer. All cash.

title: Yankees Edge Rays Behind Luis Severino and Aaron Hicks to Sweep Series
description: In the hierarchy of things unlikely to happen in a Yankees game, it is hard to determine which would rank higher: Luis Severino winning as a starting pitcher, or Aaron Hicks hitting two home runs. Neither had happened in quite a while.

title: Le Pens Inner Circle Fuels Doubt About Bid to Un-Demonize Her Party
description: PARIS  Little more than a week before Frances presidential election, Marine Le Pen remains a front-runner after working hard to sanitize the image of her party, the National Front, and to distance it from the uglier associations of Europes far right.
Thomas Hooven12

title: A Dose of Empathy From My Syrian Doctor
description: He lifted his glasses and let them rest on his forehead before taking hold of my right leg. Pull me closer, he said.

title: New Zealand Showcases Its Appeal
description: A nation working to be a tech hub is finding that part of what makes it attractive to potential hires is its distance from some of the worlds frustrations.

title: As New Zealand Courts Tech Talent, Isolation Becomes a Draw
description: WELLINGTON, New Zealand  In the South Pacific, software no longer needs a hard sell.

title: Turks Across the West Wring Hands as Vote Looms
description: As Turkey heads to a referendum on Sunday to expand the powers of the presidency, Turkish voters living abroad could play an important role in the outcome. In some European countries with large Turkish populations, tensions have been high recently: Officials from President Recep Tayyip Erdogans party, known in Turkey as the A.K.P., tried to campaign in Germany and the Netherlands and, when rebuffed, responded with a stream of harsh  insults.

title: Turkish Diaspora Weighs In on Erdogans Bid to Bolster His Power
description: ISTANBUL  Throughout the campaign in Turkey over a referendum to bolster the powers of the president, which concludes with a vote on Sunday, President Recep Tayyip Erdogans government has been locked in a bitter row with a number of foreign countries.

title: Turkeys Erdogan: Democracys Savior or Saboteur?
description: ANKARA, Turkey  The political career of Yasar Yakis, a former foreign minister of Turkey, offers a telling look at the trajectory of the countrys president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan.

title: Afghanistan, Marine Le Pen, Vin Diesel: Your Friday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: Witnessing an ISIS Drone Attack
description: Embedded with Iraqi special forces, Ben C. Solomon was on the front lines in Mosul when a threat came from above: An ISIS drone dropping a grenade.

title: Whats on TV Friday: Fortitude and Mystery Science Theater 3000: The Return
description: Fortitude, which brought terror to the Svalbard archipelago in Norway, moves to Amazon Prime and adds Dennis Quaid to the cast. And Mystery Science Theater 3000: The Return, on Netflix, reboots the beloved schlocky classic.

title: Siege Has Ended, but Battle Over Public Lands Rages On
description: BURNS, Ore.  A year ago, this corner of rural Oregon became center stage in the drawn-out drama over public lands when armed militia leaders seized a national wildlife refuge, arguing that the government had too much control of land in the West.

title: With Power From the Mets Bench, Michael Conforto Preserves His Role
description: MIAMI  Juan Lagares, the Mets defensive-minded backup outfielder, returned from his oblique injury on Thursday, which a week ago would most likely have meant that Michael Conforto would have been sent to Class AAA Las Vegas to play every day.

title: The Week in Pictures: April 14, 2017
description: Photos by The New York Times and by photographers from around the world.

title: Right and Left: Partisan Writing You Shouldnt Miss
description: The political news cycle is fast, and keeping up can be overwhelming. Trying to find differing perspectives worth your time is even harder. Thats why we have scoured the internet for political writing from the right and left that you might not have seen.

title: The Week in Pictures: April 14, 2017
description: Photos by The New York Times and by photographers from around the world.

title: A Centenary and Recent Discoveries Shine a Spotlight on Rodin
description: LONDON  Sometimes money tells us something interesting about an artist.

title: The Point of Hate
description: On Palm Sunday, two suicide bombers killed 44 worshipers at Egyptian churches. What compels someone to do such a destructive  and self-destructive  thing? The fundamental answer is simple: hate. But theres nothing simple about hate.

title: Another Degree of Suffering in Libya
description: Libya has become a vortex of human suffering, sucking in thousands of desperate migrants. They cross the Sahara to escape war, terrorism and destitution. Upon arrival many are held hostage by traffickers and starved, beaten and tortured. Now comes yet another level of horror, with the revelation that some are being publicly sold as slaves, according to reports by the International Organization for Migration documented this past weekend.

title: The Cuomo College Fiasco
description: Donald Trump sets the bar very high, but the award for the worst public policy idea of the year goes to New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo.

title: Auditing the Auditors
description: The reputation of KPMG, one of the Big Four accounting firms, took another hit this week, when it fired five partners, including the head of its audit practice in the United States, for unethical behavior. The firings come on top of existing questions about the firms policies and practices: KPMG has for years been the auditor of scandal-scarred Wells Fargo and was the longtime auditor of problem-plagued FIFA, the world soccer governing body. Year after year, KPMG auditors saw no evil in either company.

title: Filing Taxes in Japan Is a Breeze. Why Not Here?
description: Ah, the blithe joys of springtime in the United States. Azaleas in bloom at the Masters, breezy picnics on balmy afternoons, Easter egg hunts  and the annual ordeal of tax forms, with helpful I.R.S. instructions like this: Go to Part IV of Schedule I to figure line 52 if the estate or trust has qualified dividends or has a gain on lines 18a and 19 of column (2) of Schedule D (Form 1041) (as refigured for the AMT, if necessary).

title: Poisons Are Us
description: When you bite into a piece of fruit, it should be a mindless pleasure. Sure, that steroidal-looking strawberry with a toothpaste-white interior doesnt seem right to begin with. But you shouldnt have to think about childhood brain development when layering it over your cereal.

title: Can Trump Take Health Care Hostage?
description: Three weeks have passed since the Trumpcare debacle. After eight years spent denouncing the Affordable Care Act, the G.O.P. finally found itself in a position to do what it had promised, and deliver something better. But it couldnt.

title: France in the End of Days
description: Paris  For some time France has been a country that does not like itself. Somewhere on the road from its humiliation in World War II to its disappointment with European integration to its discomfort with globalization, France slid into moroseness. High-speed trains purred; France pouted. Grumbling became a way of life, the response to lost grandeur. Now France seems ready to vent this slow-ripening anger in an election that could see the extreme right return to power for the first time since the 1940s and Europe revert to a turbulence not seen since that epoch.

title: Explaining the Health Payments That Trump Has Called Ransom Money
description: The subsidies at the heart of an Obamacare dispute are back in court today. In April, we described the stakes for the case, and the preferences of the players. Now that the case has reached a possible turning point, weve updated our analysis.

title: 5 Hours, 38 Minutes and 16 Innings: Mets Grind Out a Win Over Marlins
description: MIAMI  Travis dArnaud jogged leisurely around the bases. After more than five hours of catching wore on his body, he whacked a go-ahead home run in the 16th inning of a zany, bleary-eyed 9-8 win over the Miami Marlins. He dropped his head as he moved.

title: 5 Ways to Get a Picture-Perfect Home
description: Staging your home to sell? Or just want to make it look irresistible on social media? Watch in 360 video as a Williamsburg loft listed for $1,295,000 at Corcoran.com is transformed to make it photo-ready.

title: Jimmy Kimmel on Legal Pot in Canada: They Must Really Want Seth Rogen Back
description: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown that lets you sleep  and lets us get paid to watch comedy. What do you think of it? What else are you interested in? Let us know: thearts@nytimes.com.

title: Razed in the Hamptons
description: With vacant lots hard to come by and buyers clamoring for ever-larger homes, even a house built little more than a decade ago might be a candidate for a teardown.

title: How to Escape From a Car in Water
description: If you get on your phone and call your parents, or your sister, or 911, you will die, says Robert May, a 21-year veteran of the Indiana State Police Underwater Search and Recovery Team. No one else will arrive in time; you have to save yourself.

title: How to Save Money on an Italian Vacation
description: Italy is an enduring popular vacation destination. But if youre looking for a luxurious getaway, it can also be pricey, according to Andrea Grisdale, the owner of IC Bellagio, a Lake Como-based travel company that sells trips to Italy. Five-star hotels arent cheap, Ms. Grisdale said. And meals can also cost a lot.

title: Behind the Cover: 4.16.17
description: Jake Silverstein, editor in chief: Lorde has been shot for a lot of magazine covers, usually in a way that emphasizes her prettiness and/or awesome hair. We wanted a picture that captured something else  her originality, her mysteriousness, her odd maturity. The mastery of shadow in this photo is amazing, and the dots, a clever nod to her synesthesia, give the whole thing a surreal beauty.

title: The 4.2.17 Issue
description: RE: TRUMP VS. CONGRESS

title: Being a Lake
description: The beginning of this poem describes an odd thought experiment: A man wonders why he has never dreamed of being a lake and then proceeds consciously to will the dream into being. The poem is so accurate and sensory that it easy to forget how suffused it is with desire for a feeling of belonging that the man has never actually had. In this way, it is a nature poem, but also an allegory for any idealized experience never to be attained. Selected by Matthew Zapruder

title: 9 Ways to Make Your Home More Photogenic
description: How photogenic is your home? Perhaps the question has crossed your mind in this snap-happy, hygge-obsessed Instagram era. Whether you are selling your apartment or listing it on Airbnb, a camera-ready home is a must. An inviting photograph can draw in people scrolling through listings online; a messy or disheveled room will quickly turn them off.

title: Judge John Hodgman on Feeding Turkeys Cheetos
description: John writes: My colleague Thomas and I work in an office complex in Austin, the grounds of which are frequented by two turkeys. During lunch, Thomas often shares his Cheetos with the birds. I argue that feeding these wild animals extruded cornmeal is cruel and inhumane.

title: The Ramapoughs vs. the World
description: The phone rang in his study and Dwaine Perry answered with the weary resignation of a man who knew what was coming. The sun was setting on a late March evening as Mr. Perry listened to the voice on the other end of the line. Go on, he said, drooping his chin into his neck. Then came an extended pause, followed by a well-practiced recital of sympathies and condolences. Well, Ill get to work, he finally said before hanging up. Time to plan another funeral.

title: Have a Banana. On Second Thought, Dont.
description: NEVER OUT OF SEASONHow Having the Food We Want When We Want It Threatens Our Food Supply and Our FutureBy Rob Dunn 323 pp. Little, Brown & Company. $27.

title: Power and Punishment: Two New Books About Race and Crime
description: (Locking Up Our Own: Crime and Punishment in Black America by James Forman Jr. was selected as one of The New York Times Book Reviews 10 Best Books of 2017. For the rest of the list, click here.)

title: The South (and the West) through Joan Didions Eyes
description: SOUTH AND WEST From a Notebook By Joan Didion 126 pp. Alfred A. Knopf. $21.

title: Chibok Girls, 3 Years Later: Anguished Parents Still Wait

title: Razing the Hamptons
description: New development in the Hamptons used to conjure up images of lavish houses popping up in the middle of potato fields. But as more farms and vacant land are being preserved as open space, ever fewer lots are available to build new homes. And with soaring land values, coveted beachfront locations already built on and surging demand for new and bigger houses with copious amenities, teardowns in the area have become more pervasive than ever.

title: A Baby or Your Money Back: All About Fertility Clinic Package Deals
description: Trying to have a baby with the aid of modern reproductive technology can feel like visiting a gambling parlor with the highest possible stakes. So consider the pitch that many fertility clinics now put in front of people like Kristi and Carleton Chambers.

title: Mother of All Bombs Killed Dozens of Militants, Afghan Officials Say
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A day after the United States military dropped its most powerful conventional bomb on caves used by Islamic State affiliates in eastern Afghanistan, officials said on Friday that dozens of militants had been killed, but that they were still trying to assess the full extent of the damage. Residents said the blast had been felt tens of miles away.

title: The Hummingbird and the Pine Tree
description: My childhood was unusual. I am thinking about this as a hummingbird darts into view. She levitates among the crocosmias that have blossomed in my yard, tubular flowers that celebrate summer in showy scarlet.

description: When Okwui Okpokwasili talks about her work, she treats each question like a knot to be unraveled, physically as much as verbally. Emphatic gestures punctuate her sentences, or complete them, as if movement might summon the answer.

title: Review: Rene Flemings Poignant Farewell to Der Rosenkavalier
description: For weeks, the opera world has been abuzz about what the Metropolitan Operas new production of Richard Strausss Der Rosenkavalier would signify for the career of the superstar soprano Rene Fleming. In recent seasons, she has been retiring her signature roles one by one, and with this Rosenkavalier, Ms. Fleming, 58, is saying farewell to one of her best: Strausss Marschallin, an attractive, worldly-wise princess in 18th-century Vienna.

title: Revival for the Notekillers, Still Noisy After All These Years
description: The student and the teacher faced each other on plain black foldout chairs. It was past 9 on a windy night, and this was David Firsts last guitar lesson of the day. The student, Karen DAmbrosi, a shy 28-year-old marketing manager at Etsy, began strumming one of Mr. Firsts electric guitars. He joined in, gently plucking a melody over her chords.

title: South Korea Election Turns Into 2-Way Race as Dark Horse Surges
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Just last month, Ahn Cheol-soo, a software mogul turned politician, looked like another also-ran for the South Korean presidential election in May. His centrist Peoples Party held only 40 seats in the 300-member Parliament. He was barely polling at 10 percent in surveys.

title: When a Potential Employer Seems Unnervingly Nosy
1892: Reading of Sultans Firman Confirms Egypts Ottoman Ruler
description: CAIRO  The ceremony of reading the Firman lasted only twenty minutes. At ten oclock exactly Eyoub Pasha, accompanied by Mahmoud Bey Choukri, Chief of the Turkish Cabinet of the Khedive, drove up in a state carriage drawn by four horses, ascended the steps of the palace, over which a canopy was placed, and handed the Firman to the Khedive.

title: Germany Strikes Offshore Wind Deals, Subsidy Not Included
description: LONDON  European governments have spent large sums of money in recent years subsidizing giant offshore wind projects in hopes of creating a clean source of energy that could eventually pay for itself. Now that moment may be here  and a lot sooner than expected.

title: China Warns of Storm Clouds Gathering in U.S.-North Korea Standoff
description: HONG KONG  China warned on Friday that tensions on the Korean Peninsula could spin out of control, as North Korea said it could test a nuclear weapon at any time and a United States naval group neared the peninsula  an American effort to sow doubt in Pyongyang over how President Trump might respond.

title: Suspect in Stockholm Attack Was an ISIS Recruit, Uzbek Official Says
description: LONDON  The Uzbek man who is suspected of steering a hijacked beer truck into a crowd of shoppers in central Stockholm last week had been recruited by the Islamic State, and had encouraged other Uzbeks to travel to Syria to fight for the militant group, Uzbekistans foreign minister said on Friday.

title: The Quiet End of Basque Terror
description: In recent days the world has witnessed terrorist attacks on innocent citizens in Sweden and Egypt. It was thus notable, and welcome, that last weekend a militant Basque group quietly ended a decades-long reign of terror. On Saturday, in Bayonne, France, the group ETA, whose assassinations and bombings killed more than 800 people between 1968 and 2010, surrendered its stockpiles of weapons.

title: Turkeys Good-Governance Referendum
description: ANKARA, Turkey  Turkish voters go to the polls on Sunday in a referendum on a new constitution that would change the system of their countrys government. The ruling Justice and Development Party, or A.K.P., introduced these amendments last December  with the support of the opposition Nationalist Movement Party  to fix flaws in the current system. Unfortunately, the governments proposals are being taken out of context. Opponents have cast the referendum as an attempt to grab power by President Recep Tayyip Erdogan rather than what it really is: an effort to improve governance.

title: Cultivating Serendipity: A Visit to the New York Times Morgue

title: Careful Where You Step! Fairy Shrimp May Be Underfoot
description: In what seems like one of Mother Natures fateful synchronicities, fairy shrimp capitalize on the highly temporary pools of water that most people take pains to avoid as they hike through spring woodlands. These are not the shrimp youll find ambling along the warm, muddy bottoms of saltwater bays; these small aquatic creatures have evolved to live in one of natures most transient environments. They are as short-lived as the forest pools they occupy, dwelling in these mysterious and beautiful worlds for a brief three or four months, and then both the pools and the shrimp vanish, fairylike, absorbed back into the forest floor like magic.

If youre lucky, you get to live a bunch of lives in one lifetime, said Mr. Theroux, 45.

title: Going Home With the Artist David Salle
description: Wichita, Kansas. Sodbusters, buffaloes, cowboys on long dusty cattle drives, Wyatt Earps jail. All that happened a long time ago. A hundred years later, I knew a landscape of tract houses, the IGA, Woolworths lunch counter and car lots, one after another, their boundaries marked by strings of colored flags. There were drive-in movies, Mexican restaurants and tall grain silos like sentinels along the railroad tracks. The straight black streets went on and on, stopping only at the wheat fields on the edge of town.

The Christian-themed musical will be the first production at the museum, and it is scheduled to run for eight weeks starting Nov. 18.

title: Signs of Life in Todd Webbs New York
description: By the time Todd Webb arrived in New York City in 1945, he had lived enough lives for several men. He lost his fortune in the 1929 crash; hunted for gold in California, Mexico and Panama; worked for Chrysler in Detroit, his hometown; and served in the South Pacific as a photographers mate. But it was in New York where his love of photography took off, though with a slight detour.

His latest was inspired by more mercenary motives: Im writing it because I was paid to write it. But this is just a feint; in her review for The Times, Sarah Lyall says Baldwin makes a sophisticated effort to understand his origins along with, as he delicately puts it, some incautious choices.

title: In Praise Of Nursing
description: For some reason Im suddenly getting a lot of mail about a sloppy and insensitive thing I did in passing in a blog post a while back. I was writing about what kind of work would survive digital technology, and described nursing among other things as menial work. Whats odd is that I have never imagined that; I dont remember what I was thinking, but I may even have meant to say manual (which is also not right, however, since theres a lot more than manual skill involved).

description: Much to the relief of Wall Street executives, who feared and hated him in equal measure, Daniel K. Tarullo left his powerful perch on the Federal Reserve Board of Governors last week, but not before delivering one last lecture on how big banks should be regulated in his absence.

title: Uniteds Apologies: A Timeline
description: The week began when video of a passenger being forcibly removed from a United Airlines fight on Sunday started to spread widely on social media. The passenger was eventually identified as Dr. David Dao, 69, of Kentucky, who sustained a concussion, a broken nose and lost two teeth during the episode. United has issued several evolving statements since Monday after  receiving criticism that it had mishandled its initial response.

title: Phil Jackson Says Carmelo Anthony Would Be Better Off Somewhere Else
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  In a season-ending exit interview last year, Knicks President Phil Jackson gave Carmelo Anthony a simple directive. At that point, the Knicks were not in a position to win an N.B.A. title, Jackson said, so he told Anthony it was his decision whether he wanted to remain with the team. One year later, after Anthony chose to stay and the Knicks completed a 31-51 season, Jackson was not as subtle.

description: Welcome to Our Picks, a guide to the best stuff to read, watch and listen to from around the internet. title: Vanguard Is Growing Faster Than Everybody Else Combined
description: MALVERN, Pa.  The Vanguard trading floor is the epicenter of one of the great financial revolutions of modern times, yet it is a surprisingly relaxed place.

title: White House to Keep Its Visitor Logs Secret
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla.  The White House announced Friday that it would cut off public access to visitor logs revealing who is entering the White House complex and which officials they are meeting, breaking with the Obama administrations practice and returning a cloak of secrecy over the basic day-to-day workings of the government.

title: Aaron Hernandez Is Found Not Guilty of 2012 Double Murder
description: Aaron Hernandez, the former New England Patriots tight end, was found not guilty of a drive-by shooting in Boston in 2012.

title: Dan Rooney: Pittsburgh and N.F.L. Royalty, and an Ordinary Guy
description: On a summer evening  any summer evening, even when the Pittsburgh breezes were kicking up a storm  he would walk a few blocks over to the park where he played as a kid, set himself down on a chair and talk about nothing in particular with Gus Kalaris. He and Gus grew up there on the North Side, fate sending Dan Rooney to the ownership of the Steelers and Kalaris to the ice ball truck his father built 83 years ago.

title: Sound and Fury
description: When I read of the United States forces dropping of the second-largest non-nuclear explosive in their arsenal  the 21,000-pound GBU-43/B Massive Ordnance Air Blast (MOAB)  in eastern Afghanistan, I am reminded of what John Paul Vann, the legendary Army officer and civilian adviser during the Vietnam War, said about the right way to fight guerrillas: This is a political war, and it calls for discrimination in killing. The best weapon for killing would be a knife, but Im afraid we cant do it that way. The worst is an airplane. The next worse is artillery. Barring a knife, the best is a rifle  you know who youre killing. An Israeli general made a similar point to me after the defeat of the second intifada, saying, Better to fight terror with an M-16 rather than an F-16.

title: I Want My Lesbian Bars Back
description: CHICAGO  Where is everyone?

title: Bachs St. John Passion Has More Humanity Than Anti-Semitism
description: How passing strange. Typically, in the lead-up to Easter, Bachs surviving Passions, the St. John and St. Matthew, each attract a performance or two in New York. But this spring, for whatever reasons, brought five major presentations of the St. John and none of the St. Matthew. And several new recordings arrived in recent weeks, all of St. John, as if to drive the point home.

title: Robert Taylor, Innovator Who Shaped Modern Computing, Dies at 85
