description: Madonna isnt too excited about a planned feature movie that will follow her early years as an aspiring material girl in gritty 1980s New York.

title: Wells Fargo Shareholders Tepidly Re-elect Banks Directors
description: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla.  Despite the turmoil that has engulfed Wells Fargo in the past year, shareholders voted to re-elect all of the banks 15 directors during a raucous annual meeting on Tuesday. But some of the board members edged in just barely, signaling that many shareholders want further changes to the banks leadership.

title: American Brandy Is Surging, Even in Whiskey Country
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  Three years ago, Joe Heron, a pharmaceutical executive turned beverage-industry entrepreneur, moved here from Minneapolis to open a distillery. But unlike the dozens of other would-be whiskey barons setting up shop in Kentucky these days, Mr. Heron and his wife, Lesley, werent interested in making bourbon. They wanted to make brandy.

title: Road Rage Cases With Guns More Than Double in 3 Years, Report Says
description: When the former N.F.L. player Joe McKnight was shot and killed last year in what the authorities described as a case of road rage, it was a high-profile example of what has been a marked increase in the use of guns in such confrontations, a new analysis shows.

title: The Sounds of Mannahatta in Your Ear
description: Another visitor to New York grumbling about the racket.

title: Made Nice, the Latest From Daniel Humm and Will Guidara, Opens
description: MADE NICE Fast-casual fare in the hands of Daniel Humm and Will Guidara doesnt yield your usual assembly-line bowl. For one thing, the nine or so items on the menu, to eat in or take out and ordered from an employee holding an iPad, do not accommodate substitutions. For another, some of the food, like the soup, is dispensed with high style from heavy Mauviel copper pots. But whether you choose the salmon rosti with smoked salmon, egg, salad and pickled onions, or the quinoa falafel with pickled beets, yogurt, cucumber and salad, its all still served in disposable bowls. Starting next week, after 5 p.m., there will be roast chicken. For dessert, the milk and honey ice cream is a play on an Eleven Madison Park classic. (In fact, many of the bowl components grew out of Mr. Humms food at his other restaurants.) The restaurant, which is splashed with a Shepard Fairey mural, can seat 31. The back half of the room is the open kitchen: 8 West 28th Street, 212-887-1677, madenicenyc.com.

title: Trump Takes Forceful Tone at Holocaust Remembrance: Never Again
description: WASHINGTON  President Trump sent a powerful message to those who doubt his will to fight anti-Semitism  and to his own supporters in the white nationalist movement  during an annual Holocaust remembrance ceremony at the Capitol on Tuesday.

title: In France, These Young Voters Dream of a President Le Pen
description: The National Fronts popularity among young people in France has been on the rise, and a 25-year-old is trying to put a fresh face on a party associated with the uglier side of nationalism and Europe's far right.

title: Standing Up to Trump
description: To the Editor:

title: Celebrating Tomboys and Others Who Challenge Gender Roles
description: To the Editor:

title: In St. Anthonys Final Days, a Scramble to Recruit Its Best Talent
description: When the news broke on April 5 that St. Anthony High School in Jersey City would shut down at the end of the 2016-17 school year, the schools famed basketball coach, Bob Hurley, and his assistant Eric Harrield began fielding phone calls from coaches at other high schools. While the callers were ostensibly phoning to commiserate, and to offer their condolences on the shuttering of the school made famous by Hurley and his powerhouse teams, Hurley and Harrield knew they had another motive.

title: Golfs Ruling Bodies Limit Influence of Video Evidence
description: The governing bodies that oversee golfs rule book relied on a dose of common sense on Tuesday by swiftly and decisively mitigating how much video evidence can influence rules decisions at televised events. The new procedure, which is not a new rule but a new decision (labeled 34-3/10) to the Rules of Golf, in effect limits the use of advanced video technology  like high-definition or super-slow-motion cameras  in making rulings.

title: The Single Most Important Ingredient
description: Growing up, I thought salt belonged in a shaker at the table, and nowhere else.

title: Marisol Estate Is Given to the Albright-Knox Art Gallery
description: In what the museum is describing as the largest gift of art in its history, the Albright-Knox Art Gallery in Buffalo is scheduled to announce Tuesday that it has been given the entire estate of Marisol, a Venezuelan-American artist who fused Pop Art imagery and folk art in assemblages and sculptures and who captivated the New York art world in the 1960s with her mysterious Garboesque persona.

title: Israeli Leader Cancels Meeting After German Official Visits Protest Group
description: JERUSALEM  It was hardly the first time a top-level meeting had been canceled over hard feelings. But when Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel called off a session with the German foreign minister here on Tuesday, it seemed a particularly sharp reflection of the tension within Israel, and with its allies, these days.

title: Imprisoned in North Korea: The Cases of 3 Americans
description: When Americans are detained in North Korea, they can expect harsh conditions, with tiny prison cells, little food or water and even less daylight. And their story line is preordained: A forced confession, a show trial, a sentence to years of hard labor with little chance of appeal.

title: With Baby in Tow, Victoria Azarenka Returns to Tennis  and Her Roots
description: MINSK, Belarus  The child care was done, if only for a moment, and Victoria Azarenka was back where it all began, leaning against the wall that had been her first tennis companion.

title: Website With Qaeda Ties Publishes Claim on St. Petersburg Bombing
description: MOSCOW  A website that has previously carried Al Qaeda messages on Tuesday issued a claim of responsibility for the recent subway bombing in St. Petersburg, Russia, publishing a statement from a previously unknown cell said to be working on behalf of the terrorist group.

title: Mens Fashion: 8 Things Every Guy Can Wear
description: Ts senior fashion editor, Jason Rider, picks the seasons essential pieces, from lightweight camping shorts to the perfect tank top.

title: Trump Rides a Market Wave, but Business Looks for Results
description: The investor enthusiasm that began with President Trumps unexpected victory in November has burst out anew on Wall Street, even as Washington remains gridlocked and evidence of any real pickup in the economy is scarce.

title: What Were Reading
description: New York Times reporters and editors are highlighting great stories from around the web. You can receive What Were reading by email, and let us know how you like it at wwr@nytimes.com.

title: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
description: $4.5 MILLION

title: Chobani Yogurt Sues Alex Jones Over Sexual Assault Report
description: Chobani, the yogurt company, has filed a lawsuit against Alex Jones, the high-profile conspiracy theorist and the host of a popular right-wing radio show, for posting what it called false news reports about the company and its owner.

title: How Wrestling Explains Alex Jones and Donald Trump
description: Alex Jones, the conspiracist at the helm of the alt-news outlet InfoWars, used an unusual defense in a custody hearing in Texas last week. His ex-wife had accused him of being unstable and dangerous, citing Mr. Joness rants on his daily call-in show. (Among his many unconventional stances are that the government staged the Sandy Hook massacre and orchestrated the 9/11 attacks.) Through his attorneys, Mr. Jones countered that his antics are irrelevant to his fitness as a parent, because he is a performance artist whose public behavior is part of his fictional character. In other words, when he tells his audience that Hillary Clinton is running a sex-trafficking operation out of a Washington pizza parlor (an accusation for which he has offered a rare retraction), he is doing so merely for entertainment value.

title: Zuri, a Brand of Colorful Dresses
description: The Kenya-based brand features only one style in an array of fabrics.

title: Brand to Know: The Kenyan Line That Makes Only One Dress
description: When preparing for a trip to South Sudan last May, the American designer Sandra Zhaos packing list was straightforward: I wanted something I could shove in a backpack, that wouldnt look like Id just shoved it in a backpack. Zhao, a New York City transplant, was living in Nairobi, where its fast and cheap to have clothes tailored, so she designed the dress she had in mind: resistant to wrinkling, airy enough for the equatorial sun and long enough (in sleeves and skirt) to be culturally appropriate. The resulting piece  a tunic-style dress thats fitted in the shoulders and loose through the body  hit all the marks. It also, remarkably, looked good. Zhao traveled in the dress; then she started living in it.

title: A Hamptons Hotel Taps Into Rhode Islands Beach Scene
description: NEWPORT, R.I.  After a makeover that made it into a luxury destination at the easternmost tip of the Hamptons on Long Island, N.Y., Gurneys Montauk Resort and Seawater Spa is bringing its name to another seaside hot spot: Newport, R.I.

title: North Korea, France, Ivanka Trump: Your Morning Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: Critics in Turkey Question Credibility of Judges Who Oversaw Vote
description: ANKARA, Turkey  The credibility of the judges who oversaw Turkeys referendum last week is being called into question because most of them were hastily appointed when President Recep Tayyip Erdogan purged the judiciary after last summers failed coup.

title: One Certain Projection in Mock N.F.L. Drafts This Year: Uncertainty
description: Making a mock N.F.L. draft is not easy. Divining the intentions of 32 teams, evaluating scores of players, factoring in potential trades and coming up with a list of picks that makes sense tests the mettle of even the most informed fan or pundit.

title: Intemperate Words, Temperate News Coverage
description: It isnt often that editors at The New York Times consider using the N-word in a story. But one noteworthy occasion arose last week when a Florida state senator went on a profanity-soaked tirade in an exclusive club with other colleagues. The senator, Frank Artiles, used not just that word but a raft of other epithets that led first to an apology and four days later to his resignation.

title: Tyson Foods Continues Expansion With Takeover of Sandwich Maker
description: Tyson Foods has found a delectable new bite to swallow in its quest to become Americas premier protein provider from the farmyard to the kitchen table. The $3.2 billion purchase of AdvancePierre, a ready-to-eat sandwich maker, takes the Springdale, Ark.-based poultry company further up the food value chain. Along with plans to carve off some less wholesome morsels, Tyson is giving investors plenty to cluck about.

title: City Commits $100 Million to Narrowing a Gap in Manhattan Greenway
description: The waterfront parkland that rings Manhattan is filled with flowers, trees, bushes, walkways and bike paths  and then theres the East Side of the island.

title: Amtrak Said to Weigh Extended Track Closings for Penn Station Repairs
description: After two derailments at Pennsylvania Station in New York, Amtrak officials are considering closing tracks at the station for an extended period to make long-term repairs  a drastic move that would cause huge disruptions for tens of thousands of commuters, according to officials who were briefed on the plans.

title: Derek Jeter and Jeb Bush Are Said to Move Closer to Purchase of Marlins
description: Derek Jeter has always said that his long-term ambition was to own a major league team. Now, less than three years into his retirement, he appears to be closing in on his chance.

title: A Spring Picnic Recipe From Two Rising N.Y.C. Chefs
description: At King, the recently opened restaurant in West SoHo from chefs Clare de Boer and Jess Shadbolt, the menu is always a bit up in the air. I think the way we cook in the kitchen is very similar to how someone would cook in their farmhouse in Provence. We dont use recipes, de Boer says. We just cook what we fancy for dinner that night. Lately, thats been everything from whipped salt cod with grilled polenta to rose veal with artichokes, which the duo  who are alums of the River Caf in London  creates using fresh, seasonal ingredients sourced from farmers markets and local purveyors. Though the menu changes daily, there has been one mainstay since the bistro debuted last fall: panisse, a crispy Provenal snack made with chickpea flour. We like to have a cold drink and a few fingers of panisse ourselves so its one of the things that sticks to the menu, de Boer says. Weve been open for seven months now, and we still enjoy it.

title: Was the Pope Wrong to Compare Refugee Centers to Concentration Camps?
description: Until last weekend, Pope Francis earned nothing but praise from the American Jewish Committee. But when the pope, speaking off the cuff, likened European migrant and refugee holding centers to concentration camps, the advocacy groups response was swift and sharp.

title: Claudia Rankine and Will Rawls: Surveillance and the Black Experience
description: It was a sticky June day in the financial district when the choreographer Will Rawls, still recovering from a performance of his piece The Planet Eaters, first met the poet Claudia Rankine. She and her husband, the filmmaker John Lucas, were investigating his work for a potential collaboration merging poetry, video and dance.

title: Review: Okwui Okpokwasili Gives Voice to the Ignored and Oppressed
description: Okwui Okpokwasilis Poor Peoples TV Room is as dense and delicate as a centuries-old tapestry. It can be oblique, but its also alive as it drifts through myriad subjects to conjure a surreal, imaginary place where, you get the distinct feeling, women have long been oppressed and ignored, or worse: treated like victims.

title: Why Abortion Is a Progressive Economic Issue
description: The Democrats unity tour fractured into disunity almost immediately after it began. Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont refused to say whether Jon Ossoff, the Democratic candidate trying to win a typically Republican district in Georgia while being outspoken in support of abortion rights, counts as a progressive. He then went on to stump for Heath Mello in Nebraska. Mr. Mello, who is running for mayor in Omaha, has sponsored legislation aimed at restricting womens access to abortion, including a bill in 2009 that required women to be informed that they could look at ultrasounds of their fetuses.

title: Review: Jimena Pazs Yellow Glows Radiant in the Dusk
description: The first scream is a shock. In the middle of an enigmatic solo, performed largely in silence in the intimate confines of the Chocolate Factory, its unsettling when the dancer shrieks like a horror movie victim. The second and third screams are less jolting, folded in with calmer activities, but they still stick out among the mysteries of Jimena Pazs Yellow, such as: Why does the performance take place two hours before sunset?

title: Turkish Strikes Target Kurdish Allies of U.S. in Iraq and Syria
description: ERBIL, Iraq  Turkish warplanes bombed Kurdish fighters in Iraq and Syria on Tuesday in an unusually intense operation that presented a new complication for the United States military campaign against the Islamic State.

title: Crowdfunding a Well-Deserved Break
description: I had hoped readers would enjoy following a food vendor around on the streets of Manhattan for a day, but I hadnt expected the story I wrote about Kabir Ahmed to take on a life of its own.

title: Aeroflot Workers Are Told Passengers Want Attractive Flight Crews
description: MOSCOW  By Russian standards, the news conference on Tuesday was unusual: an airing of grievances by two female flight attendants who had taken the rare step of suing Aeroflot, the countrys flag carrier, for age and sex discrimination.

title: Greg Marius, Impresario of Harlem Street Ball, Dies at 59
description: Greg Marius, who helped make street basketball big business when he founded a tournament in Harlem that let playground standouts share the court with professional stars in a raucous atmosphere of dazzling play, hip-hop music and exuberant crowds, died on Saturday in Harlem. He was 59.

title: Review: Obit Follows the Team That Writes Death Notices for The Times
description: As a reviewer, I wouldnt blame readers if this section werent the first thing they turned to in their newspapers. It is, after all, some distance from the obituaries, and priorities are priorities. Perhaps, they too are inclined to read the obits as soon as possible, even to the point of bypassing the front page  unless of course it carries a piece about somebody famous who died, unexpectedly or not.

title: Milwaukee Inmate Died After Being Deprived of Water for 7 Days
description: Inmates, correction officers and investigators are testifying in Milwaukee this week to help determine whether jail employees will be charged with abuse in the dehydration death of an inmate who the authorities say was deprived of water for a week.

title: Deadly Heist Shakes a South American Borderland Trying to Shed Its Lawless Image
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  The heist was cinematically daring even for the South American borderland famed as a smugglers haven.

title: Review: Bang! The Bert Berns Story, With Juicy Showbiz Lore
description: His career barely spanned a decade, but the songwriter, record producer and music entrepreneur Bert Berns put his fingerprints on a sufficient number of pop and R&B hits in the 1960s to amass a canon that rivals Phil Spectors. As it happens, a new documentary about Bernss too-short life (he died in 1967 at 38), Bang! The Bert Berns Story, reveals that he resolved to take more control over his music after witnessing Mr. Spector botch one of his songs in a studio session for Atlantic Records.

title: An Artist Fears Shes a Fraud in A Line Made by Walking
description: A LINE MADE BY WALKINGBy Sara Baume308 pages. Houghton Mifflin Harcourt. $25.

title: Judge Blocks Trump Effort to Withhold Money From Sanctuary Cities
description: A judge in San Francisco on Tuesday temporarily blocked President Trumps efforts to starve localities of federal funds when they limit their cooperation with immigration enforcement, a stinging rejection of his threats to make so-called sanctuary cities fall in line.

title: A Debate Over the Home of New Yorks Fashion Industry
description: Forces fighting for the future of New York Citys fashion industry came to a head on Monday evening in the less-than-chic but nevertheless most fitting of places: the auditorium at the High School of Fashion Industries in Manhattan.

title: Bringing Tito Puentes Fire to a New Generation
description: There was a sense of long-awaited catharsis on Saturday night at the Hostos Center for the Arts and Culture in the South Bronx, as the Mambo Legends Orchestra plowed through a blazing set of Tito Puentes most famous tunes. It was a proud capstone on the centers three-day festival, Tito Puente Retrospective: 50 Years of El Rey, which was both a celebration and a corrective.

title: Benjamin R. Barber, Author of Jihad vs. McWorld, Dies at 77
description: Benjamin R. Barber, a political theorist whose 1995 book, Jihad vs. McWorld, presciently analyzed the socioeconomic forces leading to the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks and a surge in tribalism around the world, died on Monday in Manhattan. He was 77.

title: Ivanka Trump, Michael Flynn, Emmanuel Macron: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Marine Le Pen May Get a Lift From an Unlikely Source: The Far Left
description: PARIS  The far-right leader Marine Le Pen faces an uphill battle in Frances presidential runoff, less than two weeks away. But she saw daylight through a small window on Tuesday, and from an unlikely source: her defeated counterpart on the far left.

title: Cuomo Hires Maria Comella, a Christie Consultant, as Chief of Staff
description: ALBANY  Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York has hired a former top aide to several Republicans, including his cross-Hudson counterpart, Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey, as his new chief of staff.

title: Getting Inside the Mind of Bach
description: Where to begin to plumb the mind of Johann Sebastian Bach, which, musically at least, seems limitless in capacity? Two radically disparate presentations in recent days struck glancing blows at the matter and suggested fascinating if not always comfortable glimpses into Bachs thought processes.

title: Fox News Racial Discrimination Lawsuit
description: The lawsuit contends that Foxs longtime comptroller engaged in racist behavior and made racist remarks and that senior executives ignored her actions.

title: 11 Sue Fox News, Citing Intolerable Racial Bias
description: Troubles at Fox News were compounded yet again on Tuesday, with the emergence of new allegations of racial discrimination at the company coming less than a week after the ouster of the networks star Bill OReilly.

title: Corrections: April 26, 2017
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Threat of Government Shutdown Fades as Trump Retreats on Wall
description: Three days before the deadline to avert a government shutdown, congressional leaders were negotiating a spending proposal on Tuesday that would supply no money for President Trumps promised border wall with Mexico but would increase funding for White House priorities like the military and other types of border security.

title: New York Citys Subway System Violates Local and Federal Laws, Disability Groups Say
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority discriminates against people with disabilities because of its widespread lack of elevators and electric lifts in the subway system, rendering it significantly more inaccessible than other cities with large public transportation systems, according to two lawsuits filed on Tuesday.

title: A Marine Le Pen Victory Wouldnt Necessarily Be a Win for Trump
description: WASHINGTON  After all but endorsing the far-right presidential candidate in France last week, President Trump has been conspicuously silent since his fellow populist Marine Le Pen finished second in the voting on Sunday and put herself within striking distance of the lyse Palace.

title: Music in the Dentists Chair
description: Dear Diary:

title: Dole Looks to Return to Stock Markets, Again
description: SAN FRANCISCO  It was a little more than three years ago when the billionaire David H. Murdock took the Dole Food Company, the business synonymous with Hawaiian pineapples, private for the second time.

title: Arthur Laffers Theory on Tax Cuts Comes to Life Once More
description: WASHINGTON  A white cloth napkin, now displayed in the National Museum of American History, helped change the course of modern economics. On it, the economist Arthur Laffer in 1974 sketched a curve meant to illustrate his theory that cutting taxes would spur enough economic growth to generate new tax revenue.

title: Lumber Tariff Adds Wrinkle to Nafta Talks With Canada
description: OTTAWA  When previous American presidents have taken trade action against Canadian lumber, it has generally been considered relatively routine. The row between the two countries goes back decades.

title: Chuck Wielgus, 67, Dies; Empowered U.S. Swimming and Apologized in a Scandal
description: Chuck Wielgus, who as the top official in American swimming was credited with doing more than anyone to make it the nations premier Summer Olympics sport, but who was later scarred by his response to accusations of sexual abuse by coaches, died on Sunday in Colorado Springs. He was 67.

title: Bucks, a Youthful Bunch, Are Facing a Bright Future
description: TORONTO  The Milwaukee Bucks are one loss away from elimination. The N.B.A. playoffs do not slow down for any team, not even for one as precocious as the Bucks. It could all come to an end for them against the Toronto Raptors on Thursday in Game 6 of their first-round playoff series. But even if the Bucks lose, it will still feel as if they are just getting started.

title: Trump Is Expected to Sign Orders That Could Expand Access to Fossil Fuels
description: WASHINGTON  After moving last month against Barack Obamas efforts to limit fossil fuel exploration and combat climate change, President Trump will complete his effort to overturn environmental policy this week, signing two executive orders to expand offshore drilling and roll back conservation on public lands.

title: Trumps Tax Plan: Low Rate for Corporations, and for Companies Like His
description: President Trump plans to unveil a tax cut blueprint on Wednesday that would apply a vastly reduced, 15 percent business tax rate not only to corporations but also to companies that now pay taxes through the personal income tax code  from mom-and-pop businesses to his own real estate empire, according to several people briefed on the proposal.

title: Quotation of the Day: Live-Streaming Classes, China Puts Youths Every Move on View
description: I hate it. I feel like we are zoo animals.

title: Without Dale Earnhardt Jr., Nascar Faces an Uncertain Future
description: Before he became one of Nascars biggest stars, Dale Earnhardt Jr. was a grease monkey. He lived in a double-wide trailer on property owned by his famous father, a seven-time Nascar champion, and worked at his fathers Chevrolet dealership, toiling on brake repairs and lube jobs.

title: The Flynn Story Isnt Going Away
description: Michael Flynn, President Trumps former national security adviser, was fired weeks ago, but his ties to Russia keep raising questions this White House wont answer and dark suspicions it cant seem to dispel.

title: Genoa Isnt Rome or Florence. Thats Part of Its Charm.
description: Why do so few people visitGenoa?

title: Like Some Humor or Spells
description: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE  As a former college student at a school that was nicknamed Molson University for good reason, I can tell you with confidence that people in college drink a good deal of beer. Its relatively inexpensive, its easy to acquire and it does its job of taking the edge off or making the imbiber feel more grown up.

title: Review: A Scam Artists Masterwork in Six Degrees of Separation
description: That dangerous young man who calls himself Paul Poitier has grown up in the 27 years since he first set foot on a New York stage. All right, perhaps not grown up, since were still talking about a narcissistic con artist of adolescent fecklessness and zero self-knowledge. But theres no doubt that he has grown in stature and, in a paradoxical way, truthfulness.

title: The Americans, Season 5, Episode 8: The Humanization of Elizabeth
description: Whats the opposite of a cliffhanger? Whatever it is, thats what The Americans ended on this week. It wasnt an anticlimax  more like a diminuendo. A mother and daughter taking a walk in the woods, sharing thoughts, and the mom  whom we know as a rigid political idealist and killing machine  musing that if she werent a spy, shed like to be a doctor. The daughter finding this funny, given her moms lack of bedside manner.

title: China, Sending a Signal, Launches a Home-Built Aircraft Carrier
description: BEIJING  Chinas first domestically built aircraft carrier slipped into the sea for the first time on Wednesday, after days of publicity celebrating the impending launch as a milestone in President Xi Jinpings drive to extend Chinas military reach far beyond its shores.

title: Rainout Gives the Battered Mets Another Day Off
description: The skidding Mets had reasons for optimism entering Tuesday. Left fielder Yoenis Cespedes and catcher Travis dArnaud were originally back in the lineup for the first time since late last week, welcome developments for a team dealing with numerous injuries only three weeks into the 2017 season.

title: What Anthony Bourdain Cant Travel Without
description: Anthony Bourdain, the host of the travel show Parts Unknown (the ninth season starts on Sunday on CNN), technically lives in New York, but averages more than 200 days a year on the road.

title: Marine Le Pen, Ivanka Trump, Israel: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: Word + Quiz: extrude
Whats on TV Wednesday: The Handmaids Tale and Gomorrah
description: The Handmaids Tale, Margaret Atwoods cautionary fable, is adapted for the screen  and to our critic, it rings especially relevant. And Gomorrah begins a bloody second season as Neapolitan crime lords take it to the mat.

title: Is There Any Benefit to Reading Books You Hate?
description: Have you ever been assigned a book for school that you simply loathed? Did you finish it? Did you learn anything, despite your dislike?

title: Cybernetics, Cesarean Sections and Soccers Most Magnificent Mind
description: PORTO, Portugal  There is an office at the end of a quiet corridor on the ground floor of the sports faculty at the University of Porto. It is not the sort of place that attracts much foot traffic, and it is not decorated as if it is intended to do so.

title: As Rising Seas Erode Shorelines, Tasmania Shows What Can Be Lost
description: ISLE OF THE DEAD, Tasmania  Maybe the hardened convicts who carved the 19th-century gravestones dotting this tiny island were barely literate, or perhaps one of them just had a wicked sense of humor. The schoolmaster Benjamin Horne went to his repose in 1843 with this sentence chiseled above his head: Sincerely regretted by all who knew him.

title: Casablanca: A City Nothing Like the Film
description: Yassine Alaoui Ismaili captures Casablancas moments of wry humor in a loving look at the Moroccan city he calls home.

title: Donald Trumps Trade Policy Is in Disarray
description: President Trumps populist, antitrade deal rhetoric was always hard to believe coming from someone who outsourced production of his clothes and other merchandise to low-wage countries like China. Now it is becoming clearer that he has no coherent plan to lower the trade deficit or bring back lost manufacturing jobs. In fact, Mr. Trumps promise of huge tax cuts might actually increase the trade deficit and hurt the very workers he says he supports.

title: It Could Be Worse
description: The first 100 days of Donald Trumps presidency have not been exactly what you could call successful, by the standards that one would normally use to judge such things. No significant legislation has passed Congress, and indeed it has become painfully clear that this White House has no real sense of what legislation it would even like to pass. There has been no political honeymoon: For this stage of an administration, Trump is the most unpopular president of modern times. Important areas of the executive branch are barely staffed or functioning, the White House is in a state of low-grade civil war, and the bungling, pratfalls, conflicts of interest, weak attempts at propaganda and brazen lying are all, well, not normal, as the self-styled resistance likes to say.

title: Lifting Kids to College
description: LOS ANGELES  If you go by the odds, Sierra Williams shouldnt be in college, let alone at a highly selective school like the University of Southern California.

title: On a Par 5 in Dubai, Good Humor and a Respite From All Things Trump
description: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates  President Trump has already played an incredible amount of golf in his first 100 days. He says he needs the break. I sympathize. In fact, I need a break, too  from him, from writing about his relentless assault on truth and science. Its toxic. So I break today to write about  golf  in Dubai, where I recently participated in an education conference.

title: Donald Trump Is a Real Republican, and Thats a Good Thing
description: Claremont, Calif.  What kind of conservative is President Trump? He must be some kind of conservative, because for nearly 100 days and counting, liberals have poured on him the kind of vitriol they do not reserve for moderates or ideological nobodys. Inside the Beltway, some famous conservatives have joined in the sport but for the opposite reason, that Mr. Trump, they claim, is no conservative but a populist demagogue out to discredit and destroy their beloved movement.

title: Questions for: Todays Energy Jobs Are in Solar, Not Coal
description: Article: Todays Energy Jobs Are in Solar, Not Coal

title: The Low-Inflation World May Be Sticking Around Longer Than Expected
description: There is a worldwide glut that includes oil wells, steel plants and eager would-be workers, and it will take more than a United States presidential election and a few months of solid global growth to fix it.

title: Casablanca: A City Nothing Like the Film
description: This week Lens is featuring photographers from around the world who have been chosen to attend the fifth annual New York Portfolio Review.

title: U.F.O.s
description: According to a recent New York Times article, sightings of unidentified flying objects around the nation more than tripled since 2001. Why do you think that is?

title: Fearing Korean Nuclear War, Women of 40 Nations Urge Trump to Seek Peace
description: SEOUL, South Korea  As the White House prepared to brief members of the Senate on North Korea on Wednesday, female activists from more than 40 countries, including North and South Korea, urged President Trump to defuse military tensions and start negotiating for peace to prevent war from erupting on the Korean Peninsula.

title: Credit Suisse Will Raise $4 Billion to Address Capital Concerns
description: LONDON  Credit Suisse said on Wednesday that it would raise $4 billion through a share sale, part of efforts by the bank to restructure and address longstanding capital concerns.

title: Genocides Legacy: Preserving Auschwitz
description: Work is underway at Nazi Germanys largest death camp to preserve the memory of the Holocaust.

title: The Founders of theSkimm Think Theyre a Gateway Drug to the News
description: Your company, theSkimm, is known for a daily news digest targeted toward millennial women, which is read by over five million people. Its tagline is theSkimm makes it easier to be smarter. What does that mean? ZAKIN: We didnt create theSkimm for lack of intelligence or lack of interest in the news. What we figured out was a way to make it easier for our readers to understand the world around them in a way that they enjoyed hearing about and in a way that made it easy to remember.

title: 5 Tips for Finding Child Care for Your Next Vacation
description: Traveling with children is many things. Relaxing is not typically among them. The exception is a trip that includes at least some help with child care  time when parents are free to luxuriate in that rarest of parental indulgences: time alone. But finding reliable, affordable child care can be enough of a challenge at home. Where does one even begin to get such help on the road? Here are five strategies for finding the right fit for your family.

title: Baking Is All in the Hands
description: My mother and I had a joke that whatever gene makes a baker skipped her generation. I think the closest she ever came to baking was spearing bright orange peanut-shaped marshmallows on a carving fork and toasting them over the stove. When I married  I was 19 and a college junior  the only culinary experience I could claim was burning down my parents kitchen seven years earlier, a misadventure involving frozen fries and boiling oil.

title: A Jamaica Trip With the Ultimate Travel Amenity: A Nanny
description: It was our second night in Jamaica, and I was sitting at a picnic table on a small, rocky beach in Runaway Bay. We were eating a buffet dinner and watching a talent show that combined sideshow stunts by performers  walking on nails and blowing flames into the sky  with gymnastics and G-rated jokes by guests, who included children and a few brave parents. When the crowd applauded, my 18-month-old daughter, Roxie, clapped excitedly with them. In the shows final act, an otherwise dignified Canadian father with Justin Trudeau-like good looks thrust his pelvis across the makeshift stage as if possessed by the spirit of Elvis Presley.

title: Rei Kawakubo, Interpreter of Dreams
description: Rei Kawakubo is a 74-year-old Japanese designer who has been making monochromatic, boiled, overstuffed, unraveling, surreal clothes since she began her label, Comme des Garons, in 1969. In the 80s, an era of triangular fluorescent shoulders and moussed bangs, she sent widows weeds trailing down the runway. In the 90s, her clothes grew tumors that resembled bustles, blurring the lines between illness and beauty, what to look at and what to look away from. While her stores stock simple cotton poplin shirts as well as more challenging lumpen jackets and her runway shows present one-off sculptures, the through-line is a thoughtful rejection of should and a strong feeling of perhaps. The name of her label, which translates to Like the Boys, is a quiet, defiant shrug.

title: The C.E.O. of H.I.V.
description: Last May, at the height of the Democratic presidential campaign, two weeks before the California primary, Bernie Sanders flew to San Bernardino, Calif., for a meeting with leading AIDS groups. The gathering was arranged by Peter Staley, the esteemed activist and founder of the Treatment Action Group, which in the 1990s helped speed the development of antiretroviral drugs. The meeting was called to secure the Sanders campaigns support for a spike in federal spending to combat AIDS, but as the session began, those in attendance were puzzled to find the conversation oddly strained. Sanderss demeanor, Staley recalled, was very wary  he was very chilly when we shook hands. Sanders seemed to be churning internally about something until, dispensing with ceremony, he blurted out: Let me be blunt. Do any of you get money from the drug companies?

title: On the Mosul Front, a Brutal Battle Against ISIS and Time
description: Mr. Gordon, a military correspondent for The Times, is working with the Iraqi reporter Kamil Kakol on the front lines in Iraq.

title: Viet Thanh Nguyen Reveals How Writers Workshops Can Be Hostile
description: Literature and power cannot be separated. American literature is read around the world not only because of its inherent value, but because the rest of the world always reads the literature of empires. A new development is that the American way of teaching writing is beginning to spread globally. The writing workshop, with all its unexamined assumptions, has spread to Britain and Hong Kong, a model of pedagogy that is also an object lesson in how power propagates and conceals itself.

title: Should I Get a Pet From a No-Kill Shelter?
description: I recently experienced the loss of a much-loved pet. I am looking into getting a new cat or cats. My dilemma is where: 1. A no-kill animal shelter; 2. A shelter that euthanizes animals if there are too many. Do I opt for the kill shelter  thereby saving lives? Or support the no-kill shelter? M. Watkin, Cobden, Ill.

title: The Man to Blame for Our Culture of Fame
description: Its gone now, replaced by a small, unobtrusive park, but in the middle of the 20th century the Stork Club, on East 53rd Street in Midtown Manhattan, was the center of an emerging national culture of celebrity. As Daniel J. Boorstin wrote in his landmark 1961 book THE IMAGE: A Guide to Pseudo-Events in America, fame, which had once been based largely on achievement or on high birth, was becoming more a matter of a person who is known for his well-knownness. And the Stork Club was the temple of the high priest of this new cult of fame for fames sake, the columnist and broadcaster Walter Winchell, who presided over a mlange of stars, athletes, politicians and the merely notable from the clubs Table 50. In Winchells reporting, The death of ten thousand people in Ethiopia was followed immediately by a Hollywood divorce or romance, Neal Gabler wrote in his brilliant 1994 biography WINCHELL: Gossip, Power and the Culture of Celebrity. Dozens of these items raced past listeners each program, not only abutting one another but most given the same urgency and drama. Nothing was differentiated. Winchells reach was enormous. One listener recalled strolling one Sabbath evening for six blocks through a residential section of Birmingham [Alabama] and never losing a word of W.W.s broadcast as his voice came through a succession of open windows.

title: Invisible Bird Killer Lurks in Revitalized New Jersey Meadowlands

title: A Timely Tribute to Abbey Lincoln
description: Known as a jazz vocalist and composer, Abbey Lincoln was also an organizer. Her work has never lost its relevance, but it feels especially pertinent today. Lincoln was living in Harlem in 1962 when she helped to establish the Cultural Association for Women of African Heritage. Her 1966 essay Who Will Revere the Black Woman? has been reprinted in various collections over the years. But her music lives the fullest afterlife. Lincolns tart drawl earned comparisons to Billie Holiday, but she matched it with a deep, bridling intensity that refused to be displaced. The sharp poetry of her lyrics conveyed only a sliver of her message. From Thursday, May 4 to 7, the Apollo Theater will host a festival of conversations and performances titled Women of the World. It culminates on Saturday, May 6, with a concert celebrating Lincolns work. The musical director, Terri Lyne Carrington, has assembled three world-class vocalists to honor Lincoln: Dianne Reeves, Dee Dee Bridgewater and Esperanza Spalding. (apollotheater.org)

title: Why Pictures Now: Louise Lawlers Examination of the Art World Comes to MoMA
description: Why Pictures Now, a career survey of the New York artist Louise Lawler, has been a long time coming to the Museum of Modern Art. Ms. Lawler was a part of the so-called Pictures Generation of the late 1970s, a group of artists who appropriated images from popular culture to consider the mechanisms of value production. She was in some ways the least noticed of the group because she addressed the emperors-clothes aspect of art through the least showy filter: She simply took photographs of objects in museums, auction houses and private collections, and revealed them to be the pricey bric-a-brac that they are. Built into her work was a view of arts fragility  and a sense of our own, which keeps us attached to it. But what does the market care? Its never been less fragile, and with this MoMA survey, which opens on Sunday, April 30, one of its most astute critics becomes one of the seasons brightest stars. (Through July 30; moma.org.)

title: The Photographer Who Captured People Driving in Los Angeles
description: I wanted to do something that would have a little humor to it, and maybe a little riskiness, the photographer Mike Mandel says. His new book, People in Cars out next month, does just that: Its a collection of snapshots he took in 1970s California as a 19-year-old kid. I grew up in Los Angeles and all of my experience of being in L.A. was about going from one place to the other by car, he recalls. He saw the automobile as an American icon and a home in itself, where people would spend hours of their time. Walking to an intersection half a block from his house, he began to take candid photographs of drivers.

title: The Handmaids Tale Series Premiere Recap: Welcome to Gilead
description: Washed-out colors  moss green, dusty blue, sunlight like aged parchment  give the premiere episode of The Handmaids Tale an almost fairy tale quality. Flashbacks depict a near-future version of the United States, full of people that use cellphones and reference Uber. But that world eventually becomes Gilead, a retrograde and repressive theocratic society in which the title characters wear Amish-like bonnets. The cinematography and the blend of signifiers from different time periods make it all feel somewhat timeless. (Which is part of the point. This could be any moment in time given the history of female oppression.) But there is one color that stands out: blood red. Its the color of the robes that handmaids like Offred (Elisabeth Moss) must wear as a mark of their position in this world.

description: Jonathan Demme, the Academy Award-winning filmmaker who died on Wednesday at 73, easily jumped genres in his work, from cerebral thrillers like The Silence of the Lambs to scrappy family dramas like Rachel Getting Married. But music  especially rock  remained a through line in his films for decades, inspiring and elevating what ended up onscreen.

title: The Back Story on Bad Forensic Science
description: With the Trump administrations move to end a commission investigating flaws in forensic science, Retro Report looks at the history of one now-challenged method: hair analysis.

title: Ta-Nehisi Coatess Between the World and Me Is Coming to the Apollo
description: Between the World and Me, Ta-Nehisi Coatess award-winning book exploring racial injustice in America, will be brought to the Apollo stage next April.

title: How Do I Get a Mortgage?
description: After making the decision to buy a home and figuring out how big a down payment you will make, you need to figure out how much you'll need to borrow and what type of mortgage you want to get.

title: What Kind of Mortgage Should I Get?
description: How to figure out which kind of mortgage is right for you and how long you'll need to pay back the money.

title: Beer Drinkers May Develop Irregular Heart Rhythms
description: The Munich Oktoberfest might seem an unlikely locale for a medical research project, but German scientists studied festivalgoers and found that moderate social drinking may lead to arrhythmias  irregular heart rhythms  in otherwise healthy people.

title: How Do I Get a Good Interest Rate?
description: The interest rate is the cost you must pay each year for your mortgage  essentially the fee the bank charges you for borrowing the money.

title: How Do Down Payments Work?
description: There's a reason why people talk about saving to buy a house. Your savings will go into your down payment.

title: After Hate Crimes, Victims Get Stuck With the Bill

title: Jesse Watters of Fox Denies His Ivanka Trump Comment Was Lewd
description: Jesse Watters, the Bill OReilly protg who recently moved to the 9 p.m. slot on Fox News as a host of the The Five, made a comment on Tuesday that critics saw as a lewd joke directed at Ivanka Trump.

title: What Are Closing Costs?
description: When you close the deal to buy your home and actually take title to the property, you will have to pay closing costs.

title: Wells Fargo Chairman Should Listen to Investors and Step Down
description: Its time to add Wells Fargos chairman, Stephen W. Sanger, to the list of firings over the creation of millions of fake accounts.

title: Agustn Edwards, Conservative Media Tycoon in Chile, Is Dead at 89
description: SANTIAGO, Chile  Agustn Edwards, the Chilean media magnate who published El Mercurio, the countrys most influential conservative newspaper, and played a crucial role in overthrowing the socialist government of Salvador Allende in 1973, died on Monday on his farm in Graneros, about 46 miles south of Santiago, the capital. He was 89.

title: A Closer Look at the Evidence
description: Reverence for science has not been a conspicuous guiding spirit of the Trump administration, and forensic science is no exception. That was affirmed this month when Attorney General Jeff Sessions ended an advisory panel created under President Barack Obama to improve the reliability of crime-solving techniques like hair analysis, ballistics testing, bite-mark evidence, blood typing and shoe-print comparisons.

title: Where to Stream Jonathan Demme Movies
description: Watching is The New York Timess TV and film recommendation website.

title: Jonathan Demme: The Directors Seven Career-Defining Movies
description: The director Jonathan Demme, who died Wednesday at the age of 73, had an eclectic filmography that spanned many genres. Heres a look back at seven of his career-defining films, with review excerpts.

title: Chided by Brussels, Hungarys Leader Attacks George Soros
description: LONDON  Hungarys leader issued a blistering attack against the American billionaire and philanthropist George Soros on Wednesday, after the European Union criticized a new Hungarian law that threatens to shut a university founded by Mr. Soros.

title: The 7 Key Elements of the White House Tax Plan
description: WASHINGTON  Here are the most important changes in the tax plan proposed Wednesday by President Trump.

title: Trump Tells Foreign Leaders That Nafta Can Stay for Now
description: WASHINGTON  President Trump told the leaders of Mexico and Canada on Wednesday that he would not immediately move to terminate the North American Free Trade Agreement, only hours after an administration official said he was likely to sign an order that would begin the process of pulling the United States out of the deal.

title: How Sylvan Esso Made Radio
description: Radio, the first single from Sylvan Essos What Now, is a song about songs: the three-and-a-half-minute singles made for pop radio formats. Amelia Meath sings about faking the truth in a new pop song/Dont you want to sing along? as the music percolates along for three-and-a-half minutes. Radio is also a collection of custom-made sounds and patterns. Here, the producer Nick Sanborn explains how Radio was constructed. (Read our full interview with the band here.)

title: Sylvan Esso Keeps Electronic Pop Human
description: Sylvan Esso, an electronic pop duo, was hoping to give an interview about its new album, What Now, under the whale: the fiberglass model of a giant blue whale suspended overhead in a central gallery at the American Museum of Natural History.

title: Downtown Art School that Warhol Started Raises its Celebrity Profile
description: At the New York Academy of Arts annual Tribeca Ball this month, it was hard to move without smacking into someone famous and thin.

title: Where to Stream Jonathan Demme Movies
description: From a Justin Timberlake concert film to several romantic comedies, here are some of the directors most interesting movies.

title: China, Donald Trump, Pope Francis: Your Morning Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: Elizabeth Strouts Lovely New Novel Is a Requiem for Small-Town Pain
description: ANYTHING IS POSSIBLEBy Elizabeth Strout254 pages. Random House. $27.

title: Marine Le Pen Draws Cheers in Macrons Hometown, and He Gets Boos
description: PARIS  Frances presidential contest moved on Wednesday to an unlikely arena: a tumble dryer factory in the countrys north where, if the far-right candidate, Marine Le Pen, did not quite humiliate her rival, Emmanuel Macron, she sure upstaged him.

title: Are There Glass Snakes in Dale Chihulys Fragile Eden?
description: The single-word, all-caps title  CHIHULY  of a new show at the New York Botanical Garden conveys immediately exactly what visitors will be getting: vibrant glass sculptures in a familiar style, one that often recalls nature, and sometimes competes with it.

title: Review: To Be or Not to Be? Oh, Who Cares? A Different Hamlet
description: The actors transformation happens gradually, in front of us, before the lights go down. As the audience settles in at the Theater at St. Clements, the performers pluck items of rich clothing from the bounty laid out onstage  a laced corset here, a gilt-edged ruff there  and piece by piece become inhabitants of Hamlets world, not ours.

title: Oakland Raiders Lure Marshawn Lynch Out of Retirement
description: Its time for the return of Beast Mode.

title: Review: Met Operas Next Music Director Captains a Blazing Dutchman
description: What do the musicians of the Metropolitan Operas orchestra think about the appointment of Yannick Nzet-Sguin as the companys next music director? The players found two ways to express their feelings on Tuesday night, when Mr. Nzet-Sguin led a revival of Wagners Der Fliegende Hollnder (The Flying Dutchman), his first appearance since the announcement last June that he would succeed James Levine.

title: For Mary J. Blige, Pain Leads to Beauty
description: Strength of a Woman, the new album from Mary J. Blige, moves like a forest fire: ruthless, wide-ranging, blunt. The heat emanating off it is palpable. Ms. Blige has been scorned, is aggrieved and is dead-set on payback. No sensible person would want to be on the receiving end of this record.

title: Protests, Taliban and a Warlords Return: Afghan Leader Faces a Tough Year Ahead
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  In another sign of a tough year ahead for President Ashraf Ghani of Afghanistan, supporters of his embattled vice president protested on Wednesday in a northern province against what they said was the marginalization of their faction in the government.

title: Modern Love Podcast: Melanie Lynskey Reads It Took a Villain to Save Our Marriage
description: On this weeks podcast, the actress Melanie Lynskey reads It Took a Villain to Save Our Marriage, an essay about a couple seeking common ground and finding it in a shared target: their street-parking, two-car-garage-owning neighbor.

title: Winners and Losers in the Trump Tax Plan
description: The tax plan the Trump administration released Wednesday consists (so far) of a single page of bullet points.

title: Decorators on Display at the Kips Bay Show House
description: This years Kips Bay Decorator Show House, open May 2 through June 1 at 125 East 65th Street, is a brick Georgian designed by Charles Platt, a self-taught classical architect, landscape architect and artist, at the turn of the 19th century. From the mid-1940s until a few years ago, the house was the headquarters of the China Institute in America, and is now on the market for $26.8 million (at 35 feet wide, its known as a superwide in broker parlance). Inside, 18 designers have expressed themselves on five floors, including a garden level. Here are 16 of them.

title: Anthem Threatens to Leave Health Exchanges if Subsidies Are Halted
description: Even as Anthem, one of the nations largest insurers, reported an improved financial picture for the last year, the company warned on Wednesday that it would consider leaving some federal health care marketplaces or raising its rates sharply if the government does not continue subsidies to help low-income people.

title: Under Cover: Fashions New Dress Code
description: Finally, summer is in sight. Savvy shoppers will want to stock up on sunscreen, ros and, perhaps most important, a new warm-weather frock of two. A good dress invites the kind of free-spirited ease that one craves as temperatures rise. And this season the news is not about showing off skin or playing into preconceived notions of femininity. In fact, as the Times fashion criticVanessa Friedmanwrotethis month, a covered-up look may just be the defining style of this decade, with more and more women eschewing miniskirts and strapless dresses for longer, looser layers. Far from being stuffy or stifling, a roomy maxidress in breathable cotton or linen is effortlessly cool  in both senses of the phrase. Here are four ways to wear the seasons top styles without baring much of anything at all.

title: An Effort to Change Cosby Optics as Trial Nears
description: Six weeks ahead of Bill Cosbys trial on sexual assault charges, one of his lawyers, Angela Agrusa, said in an interview released Wednesday that one focus of her defense will be to change the optics for a defendant who she said many people have already decided is guilty of abusing women.

title: How Hulu and The Handmaids Tale Revived 2 Careers
description: On Wednesday, one of the most anticipated television shows of the year, The Handmaids Tale, had its premiere on the streaming service Hulu. Reviews for the series have been rapturous, and it could provide Hulu with an elusive signature hit.

title: Selections From a Saint
description: Grace Paley (1922-2007) is best known  renowned, even  for her short stories. Her Collected Stories should be on the shelf of any serious fan of the form. A new anthology, A Grace Paley Reader, contains some of those stories, a selection of poems and several essays that show a different side of the writer.

title: In Mexico, an Epidemic of Fuel Thefts Becomes a Crisis
description: SAN SALVADOR HUIXCOLOTLA, Mexico  Some of the days first customers pull into the produce market at dawn, but not with fruit and vegetables on their minds. Theyre looking for cheap, stolen gasoline.

title: This Isnt Tax Policy; Its a Trump-Led Heist
description: What do you do if youre a historically unpopular new president, with a record low approval rating by 14 points, facing investigations into the way Russia helped you get elected, with the media judging your first 100 days in office as the weakest of any modern president?

title: Simple Rule for Calculating Where You Stand on College Savings
description: Saving for college is daunting, as the sticker price for even state schools edges ever higher.

title: Justices Alarmed by Governments Hard-Line Stance in Citizenship Case
description: WASHINGTON  Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. tried to test the limits of the governments position at a Supreme Court argument on Wednesday by confessing to a criminal offense.

title: Trump, Jonathan Demme, Ann Coulter: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Inexpensive Drug Prevents Deaths in New Mothers, Study Finds
description: An inexpensive generic drug that saves the lives of wounded soldiers and civilian car crash victims has now been shown to rescue women suffering hemorrhages in childbirth.

title: Ex-Theater Agent Admits to Tricking Friends Into Investing in Fake Play
description: A former theater agent who tricked his friends into backing a nonexistent Broadway play that he said would star the actress Lupita Nyongo pleaded guilty on Wednesday to stealing about $200,000 from investors.

title: Leonard Reiffel, Who Studied Lunar Nuclear Bomb, Dies at 89
description: Leonard Reiffels many achievements as a physicist included two entirely unrelated things  one a down-to-earth development that changed sportscasting and another a far-fetched idea that, had it happened, might have changed the course of history.

title: In Ann Coulters Speech Battle, Signs That Conservatives Are Emboldened
description: Without uttering a word to students at the University of California, Berkeley, Ann Coulter on Wednesday made herself the latest cause clbre in the rapidly escalating effort by conservatives to fight liberals on what was once the lefts moral high ground over free speech on campus.

title: Russia Bans Group Led by a Kremlin Critic as More Protests Loom
description: MOSCOW  The Russian government moved on Wednesday to defang efforts to stage antigovernment rallies this weekend by blacklisting the coordinator, Open Russia, an organization founded by the Kremlin critic Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky.

title: What Changed in the Health Repeal Plan to Win Over the Freedom Caucus
description: A month after pulling their health care overhaul bill from the floor, House Republicans are growing increasingly confident that they may have found a way to pass it.

title: Berkeley Is Under Attack From Both Sides
description: BERKELEY, Calif.  The University of California, Berkeley, and the community around it have been symbols of free speech for more than 50 years. We still celebrate the legacy of Mario Savio and others who fought in the 1960s to ensure that the First Amendment be honored on campus.

title: Choate Scrutinized on Reporting of Abuse Claims
description: Connecticuts Department of Children and Families has asked the states highest criminal law enforcement agency to investigate whether employees at Choate Rosemary Hall failed to report multiple allegations of sexual abuse to the authorities, which they are required to do by law.

title: The Smile Didnt Mean What He Thought
description: Dear Diary:

title: Do Women Have to Register for the Draft? No. But Misinformation Spreads.
description: Women do not have to register for the United States draft. And no American has been pressed into involuntary service since the last draft, during the Vietnam War.

title: Curb the Use of Overseas Tax Havens? Yes! But How?
description: Wherever one may land on the applause-o-meter wired to President Trumps latest outline for a tax makeover, it aims to fix an aspect of the code that pretty much everyone agrees is broken: the way the global profits of American corporations are taxed.

title: De Blasio Proposes $84 Billion Budget as Possible Federal Cuts Loom
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio on Wednesday proposed an $84.9 billion operating budget for New York City that included new spending to provide legal services to immigrants  a nod to changing federal policy under President Trump.

title: Rangers and Senators Captains Lead by Different Examples
description: KANATA, Ontario  Erik Karlsson, the top defenseman of the Ottawa Senators, does not have much in common with Ryan McDonagh, his Rangers counterpart, when it comes to on-ice style.

title: State Police Will Help Battle MS-13, Cuomo Says
description: BRENTWOOD, N.Y.  Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo traveled to this community in Suffolk County on Wednesday to announce the creation of an anti-gang policing initiative to combat MS-13, the brutal transnational gang that he called a current scourge on the area.

title: President Trumps Laughable Plan to Cut His Own Taxes
description: As a rule, Republican presidents like offering tax cuts, and President Trump is no different. But the skimpy one-page tax proposal his administration released on Wednesday is, by any historical standard, a laughable stunt by a gang of plutocrats looking to enrich themselves at the expense of the countrys future.

title: Corrections: April 27, 2017
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Kevin OLeary, Reality TV Star, Ends Bid to Lead Canadas Conservatives
description: OTTAWA  Kevin OLeary, a political novice who used the attention he garnered from appearing on reality television shows to become a contender to lead Canadas Conservative Party, unexpectedly pulled out of the race on Wednesday.

title: Trump Orders Review of Education Policies to Strengthen Local Control
description: WASHINGTON  President Trump issued a sweeping review of federal education policies on Wednesday in an executive order to pinpoint areas where the government may be overstepping in shaping operations of local school systems.

title: Quotation of the Day: Bird Killer Lurks in Transformed Wasteland
description: That bird is pretty well torched  I dont know what else to say.

title: The Drumbeats Dont Add Up to Imminent War With North Korea
description: WASHINGTON  President Trump summoned all 100 members of the Senate for a briefing by his war cabinet on the mounting tensions with North Korea. An American submarine loaded with Tomahawk missiles surfaced in a port in South Korea. Gas stations in the North shut down amid rumors that the government was stockpiling fuel.

title: Trumps Tax Plan Is a Reckoning for Republican Deficit Hawks
description: WASHINGTON  As President Trumps top economic advisers faced a barrage of questions on Wednesday about the tax plan they had just unfurled, there was one that they struggled most to answer: how to keep the massive tax cuts they proposed from ballooning the federal deficit.

title: Ivanka Trump Parts Ways With Her Father on Syrian Refugees
description: WASHINGTON  Ivanka Trump, juggling dual roles of White House adviser and daughter of the president, said in an interview aired on Wednesday that the United States might need to admit more refugees from Syria, a pointed public departure from one of her fathers bedrock populist positions.

description: AVONDALE, La.  On April 19, 2016, Andy Pazder was sipping a cup of coffee, reading the sports page and soaking in the ocean view just a few miles from PGA Tour headquarters in Florida when the idea struck him.

title: What Trumps Tax Proposal Will Cost
description: A point-by-point look at how much it will increase the federal deficit.

title: Isnt That Something
description: THURSDAY PUZZLE  Everyone loves a bargain, and today Todd Gross returns to offer us two games for the price of one.

title: Review: Singing and Dancing the Postwar Blues in Bandstand
description: Bandstand, an openhearted, indecisive new musical, wants you clapping your hands and clenching your fists, tapping your toes and blinking back tears. It is both a peppy celebration of can-do spirit and a more somber exploration of what American servicemen experienced when they marched home from World War II.

title: He Tweeted About Chinese Government Corruption. Twitter Suspended His Account.
description: Twitter on Wednesday briefly suspended the account of a Chinese-born billionaire who was using the social media service to publicize allegations of corruption against top Communist Party officials.

title: Venezuela Says It Will Leave Pro-Democracy Organization
description: BOGOT, Colombia  Venezuela said Wednesday that it would pull out of the Organization of American States, which has long been critical of President Nicols Maduros unyielding accumulation of power at the expense of the countrys democratic institutions.

description: BOSTON  A dank and dreary night, a head-over-heels flip into the stands and a jittery performance from Yankees closer Aroldis Chapman could not put a damper on Aaron Judges 25th birthday.

title: Trumps Buy American Push Ruffles Some Fashion Feathers
description: Its America first, you better believe it, President Trump said, standing over a tool cabinet at the Snap-On Tools headquarters in Kenosha, Wis., where he signed his Buy American, Hire American executive order this month to favor American companies for federal contracts.

title: Beyonc 3.0: The Maternal Ideal
description: She may have dropped out of headlining Coachella this month because of her pregnancy, but Beyonc has not dropped out of public life. Instead, she has swapped a festival stage for an Instagram stage, and so  just in time for what would have been her second concert performance  she released a performance of a different kind: a photo shoot showcasing not her songs but her stomach, framed by a batwing tunic, over-the-knee suede boots and mirrored glasses. Followed shortly thereafter by a white-gowned Easter extravaganza.

title: 36 Hours: Tokyo
description: Spend 36 hours in Tokyo and try unique fashion trends, stroll through neighborhoods in full bloom and and catch a Yomiuri Giants game.

title: In Lima, Peru, History and Culture Run Deep
description: My surfing instructor, Johnny Linares, was sizing up my form as one might look at an underwhelming used car on the dealer lot. O.K., he said. Its not bad. But you have to push up faster and get on your feet. Get on your feet, my friend!

title: Barnes & Noble Names Chief Executive, Its Fourth Since 2013
description: Eight months after the bookstore chain Barnes & Noble ousted its chief executive, Ronald Boire, ending a brief, tumultuous tenure, it has hired a successor from its own ranks.

title: Far-Right Leaders Loathe the European Parliament, but Love Its Paychecks
description: STRASBOURG, France  Marine Le Pen, the far-right leader trying to become president of France, already has a day job as a lawmaker in the European Parliament, a position she regards with open contempt. She misses votes, mocks the process and cheers for the demise of the European Union.

title: Mets Fog Still Doesnt Lift in a Loss to the Braves
description: A Dickensian fog encircled Citi Field before the first pitch of the Mets game against the Atlanta Braves on Wednesday. For the Mets, who have stumbled in the opening month of a season that carried great expectations, the hazy conditions could have been perceived as an ominous sign of troubles to come.

title: France, United Airlines, Maria Sharapova: Your Thursday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: Europes Central Bank Sounds a More Upbeat Tone
description: FRANKFURT  With crucial elections approaching in France, the European Central Bank opted on Thursday against rocking the boat, leaving its monetary policy unchanged for the 19 nations using the euro.

title: United Takes Added Steps to Win Back Customers and Avoid More Ugly Events
description: United Airlines, still trying to regain its footing more than two weeks after a video showed a police officer violently dragging a passenger off a plane, on Thursday provided its fullest account yet of the episode and announced a series of steps meant to keep such an event from happening again.

description: After Lujan Agusti encountered dancing clowns during a religious procession, she set out to create surreal, colorful portraits that explore their complex history.

title: 21,587 Reasons to Fix Forensic Science
description: Last week, prosecutors in Massachusetts agreed to throw out more than 20,000 drug convictions dating back to 2003 because a single crime lab chemist, Annie Dookhan, admitted in 2012 that she had doctored or completely made up drug test results for years.

title: The Roberts Court, 2017 Edition
description: A Supreme Court quiz: Who offered this paean to judicial restraint: If it is not necessary to decide more to a case, then in my view it is necessary not to decide more to a case?

title: Election Tests Indonesian Democracy
description: In the two decades since Indonesia ousted its last dictator, the country has evolved into a democracy based on tolerance and a moderate interpretation of Islam, an encouraging trend in a world where authoritarianism and religious extremism are on the rise.

title: Sowing Climate Doubt Among Schoolteachers
description: PAUL SMITHS, N.Y.  The Heartland Institute, a conservative think tank known for attacking climate science, has been mailing a slim, glossy book to public school teachers throughout the United States. The institute says it plans to send out as many as 200,000 copies, until virtually every science educator in America has one.

title: Spreading Plan C to End Pregnancy
description: After lunch on a Saturday in late January at her home in Los Angeles, Francine Coeytaux, 63, an abortion rights activist, retrieved a Priority Mail envelope from her office and announced to her guests, a group of young women she had recruited to her cause, the results of a recent experiment. A couple weeks ago, we Googled abortion pills and tried ordering from a few of the sites that came up, she said.

title: Trumps Cant-Do Record
description: Well, heck, who said Donald Trump isnt going to accomplish anything in his first 100 days? All of a sudden theres a one-page tax plan and a raft of deal-making, while the Senate was bused over to the White House grounds for a briefing on North Korea.

description: This week Lens is featuring photographers from around the world who have been chosen to attend the fifth annual New York Portfolio Review.

description: Contrary to Donald Trumps indiscriminate portrayal of African-Americans as living in hell, the black upper middle class is ascending the economic ladder at a faster rate than its white counterpart.

title: The Trump Administration: 100 Days in 2 Minutes
description: A whirlwind tour of the triumphs and setbacks that marked the first 100 days of Donald J. Trumps presidency.

title: Letter of Recommendation: Pistol Petes Homework Basketball
description: When I was 12, shortly after I joined a youth-basketball team, my father summoned me to the living room. He was holding a set of VHS tapes called Pistol Petes Homework Basketball, which he thought might help me get ready for the coming season. Naturally, I was dubious. In what sense could basketball be considered homework? And who was Pistol Pete Maravich anyway? With the solemnity that other fathers adopt when passing down heirloom rifles, Dad handed me the tapes and said, Just watch.

title: What Caused This College Students Stomach Pain and Vomiting?
description: The stretcher carrying the 19-year-old woman was hurried into the emergency department of Banner University Medical Center in Tucson, Ariz. Her breath moved in and out erratically. Her jaw was clenched shut, and she held her arms stiffly at her side.

title: A Tinkerers Ideal Project, Near Norwalk Harbor
description: William Rhodes wanted to buy a single-family house in Fairfield County, Conn., not far from where he grew up in Darien.

title: Is Live-Streaming Classrooms a Good Idea?
description: Video cameras are all around us  in stores, on the street and on smartphones. Do you like being videoed? If so, under what conditions? Have you ever been videoed without your knowledge or consent? If so, what happened, and how did you feel?

title: 36 Hours in Tokyo
description: This sprawling megalopolis can be dizzying, but a selection of neighborhoods offers just the right balance of art, nightlife and cuisine.

title: Provence in a Bowl
description: Jessica B. Harris stepped out of her pink cottage in New Orleans and into the sun. She took the stairs carefully, in gold boat shoes, her shoulders draped in flowing fabric, a Zuni necklace of tiny multicolored animals swaying around her neck.

title: Life with a Rare Genetic Disease: The Science, the Suffering and the Hope
description: MERCIES IN DISGUISE A Story of Hope, a Familys Genetic Destiny, and the Science That Rescued Them By Gina Kolata 262 pp. St. Martins Press. $25.99.

title: David Grann: By the Book
description: The author of The Lost City of Z and Killers of the Flower Moon thinks the president should read The Road, by Cormac McCarthy, because it gives a sense of the fragility of the world.

title: The Other Side of Anne of Green Gables
description: Do you know Anne Shirley? You would like her. Everybody does. A lively and optimistic survivor with a feverish imagination and unchecked enthusiasms, she is a redheaded outsider who becomes an insider without forsaking her peculiarities or her intelligence. An inadvertent feminist, an unrepentant romantic, a hot-tempered sprite, shes impulsive, shes dramatic, shes smart, shes funny, she insists on spelling her name with an E at the end because it looks so much nicer. She speaks in exclamation marks and italics even when in the depths of despair, which, as an abused child, she knows a thing or two about. She is perpetually seeking kindred spirits. She loves trees and stories and nut-brown hair and will burn whatever is in the oven while dreaming about trees and stories and nut-brown hair. She can heal an infant with the croup, but she cannot tie [herself] down to anything so unromantic as dishwashing at thrilling moments or be asked to eat anything so unromantic [as boiled pork and beans] when one is in affliction. She is small and freckled and indefatigable. She is nearly 110 years old.

title: Tillerson in No Rush to Fill Nearly 200 State Department Posts
description: WASHINGTON  The stampede of diners who once rushed through the State Departments vast cafeteria has ebbed, with diplomats who previously grabbed quick bites between meetings now lingering over Korean barbecue and checking their phones for some kind of news.

title: A Business Deal and a Murder, Seen Through the Rearview Mirror
description: WESTFORD, Mass.  A silver 2006 Toyota 4Runner. Mint condition. Only 12,000 miles on the odometer. This is what the car dealer in East Providence, R.I., had to offer an up-and-coming star with the New England Patriots when he arrived at the lot in 2010.

title: 3 New Bridges Rise in New York, With Looks That Could Stop Traffic
description: New York, the city of perpetual arrival, is getting three new gateways: diaphanous cable-stayed bridges that look almost too ethereal to bear the load of thousands of vehicles and people each day. They are already transforming the skyline. With luck, they may even improve the drive.

title: How Mac DeMarco Became the Lovable Laid-Back Prince of Indie Rock
description: LOS ANGELES  Before Mac DeMarco bought a lovely blue home with a pool on a quiet hill here in Silver Lake  the first real adult spoils of a surprising career built on seeming like an affable deadbeat  he gave out his exact address to fans, not exactly expecting them to show up in droves.

description: When the Trump administration unveiled its outline of a tax plan on Wednesday, officials trumpeted a bold promise to shave the corporate tax rate to a flat 15 percent and sharply reduce taxes for ordinary Americans.
